I love technology and have 7 tablets, 1 Fitbit, 3 or 4 small speakers, 3 bluetooth headsets, a cell phone, a Fitbit tracker and heaven only knows what else -- that's a lot of little devices that take up space but not as much aspace as the chargers and their large cables.  I tried to organize everthing in the top two drawers of my half-height white file cabinets but I could not keep the cables from springing up at me every time I opened the drawer.  These little boxes proved to be gems as if designed specially for that purpose.  I now have 6 chargers and cables permanently mounted on a very innovative surge protector that I purchased at Amazon -- it has a little switch in front of each of the six electric plugs so that I only switch on a plug when I am ready to recharge a tablet or other device.  Because of the number of devices I have and the kinds of cables they use in addition to charging cables -- audio cables of all kinds and lengths, I often have to retrieve a cable from the drawer.  No shock now when I open that drawer because everything is neat and easy to find.  I also use them to hold tacks, paper clips, pennies and other loose change, lead and erasers for my automatic pencils,  These were designed, I think, for scrapbooking but they are perfect little boxes for a number of items.
Worth the money.

reviewText:
I have used the Samsung ML-1250 black-and-white laser printer for a long time and have really liked it. I got this unit and replaced it -- this new one has scanning and copying functions that the 1250 does not.

The prints are really good -- very crisp and sharp. The scanner is good and so is the copier. (I haven't used the fax option -- I haven't sent a fax in a long time.) And the ability to print true double-sided prints is for me *so* worth ditching my old Samsung printer.

For the money, a solid b&w option for the small office. I'd give the printer five stars, but the replacement toner cartridge isn't cheap and to my mind the optimal laser printer would come with more reasonably priced toner.
summary: Great black and white laser prints

reviewText:
I am really glad we were able to find an autofeed scanner that double-sides for a reasonable price. We chose this over the Fujitsu Scan Snap because it seemed more solid and I think it takes more papers at a time.

I can see why there are many people split between 4 stars and 5 stars. I debated giving it 3, but felt it was a good product, just annoying at times.

Here are the CONs that I wish weren't so:
- There was no bundled software for all of the growing population of Mac users, including myself. This is ridiculous and crazy! I had to download a free version of VueScan and work around the shareware limitations.
- When you put the paper in, it kind of teeters on the feeder "feet" that pulls the papers in. This is a problem because it consistently scans the pages off-kilter. It doesn't feel "right" when you just leave the paper sitting on top of the feeder -- it feels like it's not in correctly or not going to be fed.

PROs:
- Price
- Seems solid (was worried Fujitsu would be flimsy)
- Volume is great -- and if you're quick, you can even load in more pages while it is still rendering the last batch, and in VueScan, it will continue to add on to the PDF if you add more papers in time.
- Auto document feeder = huge time saver.
- Double-sided option = huge time saver.
summary: Thankful it exists at this price level, but some issues.

I bought the Epson RX595 because it was on an amazing sale and you can't go wrong with an Epson scanner. However, the printer is an entirely different story. After four months the yellow cartridge  ran out (Epson ALWAYS goes through yellow like crazy - they must only 1/2 fill the cartridges). I got a new yellow cartridge and put it in and then got a message that it did not recognize the Black cartridge - even though it was still at least half full. Got a new black and put it in and then the other four cartridges suddenly were unrecognizable. Bought a complete color pack and replaced all the cartridges. It worked fine for two months and now they are all suddenly unrecognizable again. They ALL still have ink.
I know this is partly my own fault because every person I have ever known that bought any Epson printer had nothing but problems with the ink. Now I'm a believer. I guess the solution is to go back to HP, even though their scanners aren't nearly as good.

The hookup to tablets goes smoothy via wifi. Copying and scanning are sheet feed rather than with a lid and screen which I haven't done for many years. The price is reasonable for what you get and the ink isn't too costly even without their automatic order plans. My usage is such that the plan sounds better than it would be in practice. But, if you use it more than I do, the plan might be a reason in itself for buying one of these. While this may not fill all of your all-in-one needs, it is handy.

I wouldn't entrust truely expensive things and expect it to stand up to a professional thief. But it's a very convenience and excellent way of getting basic protection from casual access. I use it to keep a firearm out of children's reach, and so that cleaning people cannot access passports, other documents or some other stuff I care about, though nothing truly valuable. First, let me say that there are some great reviews on here.  I learned more about this computer from the reviews already written than I did from reading over the manuals.  I learned about features that I would have never thought about.  Amazon is awesome and reviewers like the ones here are part of what makes it so awesome.

My review is going to come from a different place. I am a casual user who wanted a printer that is FAST, and had office multi-function capabilities.

For me, with a Windows 7 computer and typical wi-fi the setup was uneventful and the printer works fine from any computer in the house.  I am even able to access it from my iPhone/Apple devices and my Android phones and devices.

The speed was one of the main draws for me with this printer.  As usual, I feel like they must print sheets of paper with the letter "a" to get their advertised speeds.  I don't get the same speeds as advertised, but this printer is FAST.  First page out seems to be the more disappointing speed, but it is not terribly slow.  Don't get me wrong - it is fast.  I just think they print some best-case scenario that isn't likely in the real world.

Overall, I don't use every feature this printer offers.  I wanted speed and this printer mostly offers that - once it get going it spits out paper fast. It is up to date and has all the modern tech, apps, wi-fi, bluetooth, etc...

It is a great printer... but there is one thing that I feel brings it down a notch.  I'm knocking a star off for the price.  This is an EXPENSIVE printer and although it is very good, we are still talking about a black and white laser printer with a lot of goodies in an era where printers have become commodities that cost virtually nothing unless they are art quality color printers.  You can fax via phone, and scan from most $99 printers.

Don't get me wrong, I'm recommending this printer all the way.  It is outstanding at everything I have thrown at it.  If you need the features of this printer, then it is a solid choice.  But if you only need a subset of these features, then you might want to find a much cheaper printer that does only the features you need at a better price.

4 stars for features and quality.

reviewText:
I have boxes of old negatives and transparencies from times long past. This clever device converts them to  digital, giving them new life. The set is surprisingly compact. In addition tot he converter, it contains four adapters (one for 35 mm slides, 35 mm negatives, Super 8 film and 110 negatives), USB power adapter, USB cable, cleaning brush and user manual. At the top of the bright green adapter are the control buttons. There is a screen for viewing and a side slot for an SD/SDHC card. The device has memory so a card is not absolutely necessary. Do not use a MicroSD or SDXC. Be sure to dust off the film you will be using. From there it is a matter of powering on the adapter, selecting the appropriate adapter to feed the film. There are options to adjust the color and to brighten or darken. Then you convert. There is a playback button so you can review and edit the converted images. The converted product can easily be uploaded to a computer. You can also view the images on a tv if it is "equipped with RCA composite ports that accept video-in signal". I have not tried that as the contained screen on the device works well.  Remove the card after powering off the device. the warranty is one year.

I liked the device and was satisfied with its capabilities. Once you get the hang of it, it is quite easy and fun to use. I don't often have the luxury of walking down memory lane and this enterprise brought back many fond memories of people and times past. It is nice to be able to preserve them to enjoy in the future.
summary: Taking Memories Out of the Box

reviewText: A very late review - probably 10 years late.  But I am clearing up the backlog of pending reviews.  Probably liked it.

I have had a workhorse Brother hl-1440 laser printer since 2004. It started printing horizontal evenly spaced bands on the pages which according to the internets is not supposed to be caused by toner cartridge or drum unit but rather by a failing roller path. Replacing toner cartridge and cleaning the existing drum unit did not solve my problem.

Since newer low end b&w lasers do not have the features or quality build of my hl-1440 I decided (at <$15) to give this a try. Order shipped promptly, installation was easy.

First page printed was crisp without any smearing or lines. Unlike some other 1 star comments the drum unit I received is actually quieter than my OEM one.

I am very happy with this unit and hope that it keeps my HL-1440 working for another 10 years.
summary: Perfect replacement Drum unit for my HL-1440 at 1/10th the price of the OEM unit.

These cards allow us to make beautiful, personalized custom cards at a fraction of what we'd pay for those overpriced, impersonal store-bought ones.  I can have 25 hand drawn Avery cards for less than the price of one fancy store-bought one, or if I print them, including ink, it would still be less than $1/card.

The kids used the Avery cards for the first time today, making some cards for a friend's birthday.  They came out looking so nice and polished.  We didn't even bother with the printer; they just drew right on them.  They will have even more fun when we've got more time to experiment, with glitter, buttons, stickers, cut outs, etc.  I'm looking forward to scanning in some of their favorite drawings and using them for cover art.  Or making a Father's Day card with a photo of the kids and their dad.  I think I'll make a birthday card for my dad from his dog, with a picture of his dog on the cover and googly eyes pasted on.

The card stock is nice and heavy, is a nice bright white that shows true colors, and is scored for easy folding.  The folds come out crisp but not at all flimsy.

Knowing Avery products as I do, I'm sure they will work like a dream in my printer, but I will update my review when I have an opportunity to do a card on the printer.

I carry it around in the Moleskine A4 folio and love that I can always have it with me to jot down any thoughts or notes without adding significant weight to my shoulder tote. It has a signature folder flap in the back, a feature I have come to love using Moleskine notebooks for a while. Despite the covers being made of paper, they are surprising durable and have withstood significant wear and tear from many journeys on planes and trains; even having gotten a bit wet at one point. They lay flat but can be folded like one would a spiral bound. I like that the back pages are tear-out although I didn't realize those until I neared the end of one of them. The pages tear out easily enough if needed so I'm not sure this is necessary; I might suggest that either all or none of the pages have this perforation. At any rate, they don't interfere with the user experience. I purchased the graph paper notebooks but they also have lined. (I find graph paper notebooks harder to find but seek them out because my handwriting and thought organization somehow improve.)

Moleskine is always more expensive and I'm not justifying their prices, but I do think they are consistently good quality products that I enjoy using. Some notebooks just make you want to write in them. These do that for me.

Amazon recommended this as one of the ink packs available for my Pixma MP980, and their compatibility checker verified it was compatible.  It's not: the MP980 requires CLI-221 cartridges.  Now I'm out $43 for the box I opened, and I've got to go through the hassle of sending the other boxes back.  In short, don't trust Amazon to determine the proper ink for your printer: go to the Canon (or other mfr.'s) website to be sure you know the correct replacement cartridges.

As you can see from other reviews, this is a common problem here.
summary: Don't trust the Amazon compatibility advisor!

reviewText:
This mouse pad is somewhat smaller than the Belkin mouse pad that I have been using for many years. But after using it for a while, I must say that it has plenty of room in which to maneuver my mouse.  The gel pad is comfortable although I prefer a little softer wrist pad. But it is soft enough.  It is certainly softer than some gel pads I've examined.  The backside of the mouse pad has a sticky surface to prevent the pad from scooting around on your desk. The actual mouse pad surface seems to have a very fine texture which should benefit the mouse's resolution. I am using a Microsoft mouse and it works very well on this surface.  The Belkin mouse pad wears out after a year or so because the cloth like surface becomes too smooth and slick.  Some mice such as Logitech's mice stop working at that point. That is why I switched back to a Microsoft mouse. My Microsoft mouse really glides surprisingly well on the surface of this 3M mouse pad. It feels almost like an air puck. The overall construction of this mouse pad is robust. The mouse pad is thick, about three sixteenths of an inch thick. That is considerably thicker than most mouse pads. I think I will take this mouse pad with me when I travel.  Sometimes on an airplane or other places, you can benefit from a thicker mouse pad.  Sometimes I use some pretty weird surfaces when I am at an airport.  I just hate the touch pads on laptops. I must have a mouse to operate a computer.

Anyway, I am rather picky about mouse pads as well as my mouse.  I can say I am more than pleased with this mouse pad and I recommend it.
summary: Very Durable, Comfortable and Colorful Mouse Pad

Paper is way too thin.
The old Ampad pads (owned by TOPS) with the dark blue top were great (and were an unadvertised 20lb), but they were changed a few months ago.
Now Ampad pads are extremely thin paper.
And TOPS pads, which I was hoping were better, have very thin paper, just slightly better than the new Ampad pads with the gray top.
S.P. Richards pads are the same.
It seems no one makes *gray* thick-paper pads like Ampad did just a few months ago.

However, AMPAD Gold Fibre 20lb pads are as thick as, and slightly better than (tear easier), the classic excellent AMPAD pads. They are a very light pleasant yellow color that is named "ivory". Expensive to get the color though, $33 for a 12-pack. This is now my replacement for the classic off-white AMPAD pads that no longer exist.
TOPS Docket Gold Writing Tablet is identical quality but white and sells for much less, $20 for a 12-pack.
I don't like the glaring letters at the top of the TOPS pad (nor white paper) -- it seems to me that glaring top letters (or dark heavy lines) distract from what you have written on the paper -- what is the point of obtrusive markings like that (TOPS product designers aren't thinking about the customer but about advertising their brand in an obnoxiously distracting way).

Update: they have worsened this paper _again_ and now the surface is rough and pencils do not write well on it.

Although I prefer pastel and off-white colors, Amazon Basics sells decent quality white and yellow pads for less than 1/2 the cost of these overpriced pads (and forget about "Tops" brand -- they are the worst of all and don't ever tear cleanly).
If you are willing to spend even more and want heavier weight beautifu paper to write on, "Ampad Gold Fibre" pads (20 weight) are fabulous. The price has doubled in the past few years (old  kind of Ampad pads that were affordable and excellent are no longer sold) but there seems to be no competition for this quality paper.
Otherwise, I recommend Amazon Basics pads if you can put up with pure white or moderately saturated yellow color (it's not too bright yellow).
summary: Very thin paper, now rough too

******
Original Review:
Good all-in-one printer with some MAJOR drawbacks. This is my fourth HP printer and will probably be my last. I will continue to use my older 990cse Deskjet for document tasks as it outputs superior print quality - rich laser-sharp texts and vibrant colors due to its PhotoREt and Layered Technology which I think HP no longer uses. I will compare this to an Epson Artisan 810 a.i.o. purchased mainly for Photo and CD/DVD media printing as it does the job very well, but the Epson lacked in the area of text quality and/or document tasks.

First of all, print quality matters, and I'm not talking about photo. The whole idea of a great all-in-one is how well it performs its duty tasks such as scan, copy, the occasional fax, and most importantly - print quality on documents using regular inkjet paper. For this the 8620 seemed to handle well, at least on the printing part.

PROS: What I like.....
Printing: It is fast and the printed texts are reasonably good compared to my Epson. Colors are also more vibrant. Though overall good and presentable but I find that the texts are not as sharp compared to two of my older Deskjets.

Auto 2-sided scanning: Very convenient and works very well. I haven't encounter any paper jamming during the trial, but this feature comes with one major flaw (read cons below)

Copying: Good, but final results differs between if using adf or flatbed. Aside from the smeared vertical scan lines when using adf (a known issue) the overall results are more 'noise' compared to scans utilizing the flatbed. There are no settings for this other than resolution and it seems to be universal.

Faxing: Works well just like any other fax machine, but this simple feature would be the least use for most people so I will not get into it much. The only issue: there isn't an option for me to 'silence' the ring whenever someone calls me at home.

CONS: What I dislike....
Scanning:  Okay, the worst of all. Read along....
As mentioned before regarding using the adf, you will have two problems, vertical scan lines and output results are different when using the flatbed. Also, scanned materials are much more noisier than my Epson.
While using the adf for scanning or copying there is a major flaw across the current 8600 series where fine thin vertical lines would occur on the finished product. This is caused by dusts and debris lodged inside the adf roller and along the scanning bed area. HP advises to clean but this seemed to be an ongoing maintenance and/or problem with no real solution or fix.

My BIGGEST problem and inconvenience is when using the 'Scan to Computer' feature. Whether you save it to pdf or jpeg it will be a long process...
It requires 6 steps to scan a document to your computer, yes SIX! To begin, you choose and press these on the screen:
1. Press Scan
2. Press Computer
3. Press Select Computer
4. Press Scan as (pdf, jpeg, etc)
5. Press Start Scan
when finished
6. Do you need to scan another: Press Yes, No.
Then you get the finished product. This is a very stupid feature which you must choose or wait at least 5 minutes for the scanned item to appear if you don't respond.

On my Epson, you choose either 'Scan to PC' or 'Scan to PDF', then choose the computer and the task starts immediately w/o having you go through all the merry-go-round or if you want to scan another item and delaying the process. Obviously if I want to, I will scan again myself.
This is a definite no no for me as I do a lot of scanning, but anyone who decides to scan a few pages would very easily get annoyed.

Scan quality:
Too much noise/artifacts. Adjusting resolution and selecting 'photo' or 'document' option did not help. This applies to both jpeg and pdf files. The scanned results from my Epson yields super smooth picture and retained its original depths and colors, also output file size are smaller compared to the HP 8620. This means better quality without taking up a lot of space.

Touchscreen:
Way too sensitive. Also being a dust-magnet, I couldn't even put a towel on top to cover the machine without having the edges swiping and initializing it from sleep. The screen is not designed for moisture-sensitive touch but rather to everything, meaning you can swipe the corners of a piece of paper and it will initialize. My towel tends to open up the 'date setting' and swapped a few years back.

Flatbed cover:
The hinges will not expand upwards for book copying. You'd have to hold the book down and cover as much as you can with the cover to reduce light.

HP Printer Assistant Software:
If you are using Windows with more than one user, you MUST install the driver software for ALL users otherwise they will get the 'Scan to PC' not enabled pop-up box every time they log in. This seemed to be a delay and will eventually 'enable' itself after a while but the box hangs indefinitely until one closes. It is a nuisance with the reminder, and the fact that the driver software needs to be installed for every user.
This doesn't seem to affect Mac users as I've only installed once and for all (three users).

I'm not even going to get into photo-printing as I know this will not compare to my Artisan 810 (which uses a 6-ink cartridge system for maximum photo quality). HP is good for office tasks, at least with my older units and it is a shame that they are only stand-alone printers. My Epson Artisan would be newest for being 5 years old, but it lacks mobile printing. The HP8620 comes loaded with features but lacking major in other aspects that I needed most. Will decide if this will be a keeper and reserve each task for each unit. But then 'clutterness' will be another issue.

For the price, I didn't really mind losing out of those few of sheets, so otherwise it's a great purchase and I really like the product.

Putting it simply, the Palm IIIxe is a five-star device. If you want just the highlights as to why, see my Short Notes below. If you want the full review, go to Detailed Notes further down.
Short Notes:
- Excellent quality overall, good ergonomics.
- 8 MB RAM, easily sufficient to store a wide variety of applications plus data.
- Has 2 MB flash memory, enough to handle upgraded (v3.5) OS.
- Sharp, clear screen. Easy to read.
- Graffiti handwriting recognition is forgiving and easy to master quickly.
- Great battery life - should last over 30 days.
- Built-in infrared port - easy data exchange between Palm devices.
- Many available software applications, often freeware.
- Excellent and thorough documentation.
- Easy to learn how to use it - very intuitive if you hate manuals.
- Syncs well with Microsoft Outlook, if you're so inclined.
- Great price - a good investment.

Detailed Notes:
Spent a lot of time deciding which Palm OS model to go with, and finally picked the Palm IIIxe, primarily for the newer OS (v3.5), the 8 MB memory and the new lower price. Looked closely at the Palm m110 and Handspring Visor, units which offered attractive prices, but with 2 MB RAM, felt they didn't have enough memory. Also considered the Handspring Visor Deluxe, but on the two models that I had a chance to try out, the screens weren't the same quality as those of the Palm IIIxe, and nobody could explain it.
You may also wish to consider the new Palm m105. See the notes at the bottom of this review for more details.
To be fair, I also considered some of the newer Windows CE devices, but was put off completely by the hand recognition software. It was too slow and hard to use, so that idea was dropped quickly. Used to use a Windows CE device made by Casio, which I put aside awhile ago. Had initially been encouraged to purchase a Palm device by one of my co-workers, but I felt that the Windows CE 1.0 device with its tiny keyboard was the way to go. Then I found out that it ate batteries at a very high rate. Lived with this for awhile, but the business of hardware ROM replacement to upgrade the unit was disturbing.
The Palm does everything I need it to, and in the month that I've had it, I've been pleasantly surprised by its versatility. The quality has proven to be excellent. The case of the IIIxe, though an older Palm design, fits the hand quite comfortably.
The Palm IIIxe comes with 8MB of memory. In useful terms, this means that you can store approximately 12,000 addresses, 5-10 years of appointments (that's about 3000 appointments), 6000 to do items, 3000 memos, 800 e-mails and many applications. The available memory has been ample to download and store a wide range of applications along with the room to store related data. The IIIxe (along with some other models) has 2 MB flash memory, enough to handle the upgraded (v3.5) OS and the built-in applications. I also went to the Palm Web site and downloaded the latest (v. 3.5.2) OS and installed it. There were absolutely no problems like I had heard about with other "Palm-compatible" devices.
The screen is sharp, clear and easy to read, indoors or outside. Though I might have preferred a bit stronger backlight for those times where there isn't much light, have learned to adapt to it quickly.
The Graffiti handwriting recognition is forgiving and easy to master quickly. One of the reasons I went to a Windows CE keyboard unit a few years ago was fear of having to learn yet another way of inputting data. I couldn't have been more wrong - it's easy and quite intuitive. What's even more important is that I'm now taking notes in meeting with the device that used to be done on paper.
The battery life is outstanding. It should last thirty days or more under regular use. Since one of my complaints with the Windows CE units was short battery life, I'm impressed.
The built-in infrared port allows you to transfer documentation directly from any other infrared enabled Palm device. This function works quite well. I've transferred memos to and from a Handspring Visor Deluxe and other Palm devices.
There are many software applications available for the Palm PDAs, including a lot of shareware and freeware. The commercial programs that are available are top rate, and you can even find applications that will let you edit Word and Excel files. You can even connect to Oracle 8I databases with currently available software.
The Palm IIIxe manuals are excellent, and do a thorough job of documentation. You may find, though, that this device is easy to learn with little reading. Its interface is very intuitive, and that's helpful if you dislike going through manuals.
This PDA syncs well with Microsoft Outlook, which is extremely useful for corporate users. This is a straightforward operation in which you place the Palm IIIxe into the supplied HotSynch cradle and push the button on the base. The HotSynch operation creates a log of what was done, so you can confirm that everything was updated correctly.
Picky point - comes with a mediocre lightweight plastic stylus. Order an upgrade (or the Palm 3-pack) immediately. You won't regret it.
You might also want to consider the new Palm m105. Though it has a smaller screen than the Palm IIIxe, it has many of the same features but is packed in the same case as the popular m100.
If you are looking for a reasonably priced PDA that can live up to its reputation, then this is a first-rate choice. The Palm IIIxe is a solid unit at a great price - an excellent investment.
(Please note that this is a re-posted review.)
summary: Palm IIIxe - excellent product and an exceptional value.

I have been looking at this printer for some time, and finally had the opportunity to evaluate one, thanks to a client who provided me a new i9900 to print several architectural photos for a Home Show display. The photos were stunning and attracted a lot of attention. I had no problem with color shifts, having calibrated my monitor and used the Canon print drivers. I used a Mac G5 and Photoshop Elements. I printed approximately 55 - 8.5 x 11 (cropped to 7 x 10.5) and 32 - 13 x 19 photos. This calculates to approx 83 sq feet of photos. I used Canon inks and Canon Photo Paper Plus Glossy. Here are the stats for the ink usage for this project:

Photo Magenta 4 cartridges

Photo Cyan  3

Yellow  2

Cyan  1

Magenta  1

Black  1

Red  2/3

Green  1/4

So ~ 13 cartridges of ink were needed to print 83 sq ft of photos. Assuming a cost of $12/cartridge, this means $156 to print 83 sq ft, or 12000 sq in. This is about 1.3 cents (.013) per square inch. So ink costs for an 8 X 10 would be $1.04, for a 13 x 19, $3.21.

Now, the part that intrigued me, how would this printer perform printing black and white? For my source I used a 2 1/4 monochrome negative that I scanned. I imported the scan into Photoshop in grayscale mode. A direct print to 8.5 x 11 Kodak Ultima High Gloss looked quite good as far as color (compared to my darkroom print). However, I don't recommend this paper with this printer since the ink will smear if water contacts it. I tried printing the same negative on Canon Photo Paper Plus and was disappointed to find that the print was tinged with green. So I began checking the print settings and here is how to correct it so the green tinge disappears. Under Color Options, make sure Color Corrections is set to ColorSync (for Macs), or None. Under Quality and Media, make sure the Grayscale box is off (unchecked). Of course make sure the media type matches the paper you're printing on. This seems to make all the difference.

Now the amazing discovery....I was checking to see how water-impermeable the Canon paper/ink combination was, so I used one of the green-tinged prints for my test. I found that by wiping the print with a damp soft cloth, the green tinge disappeared and a beautiful, neutral black and white print appeared!!!

I'm not sure what is happening here, since if I wipe a color print on Canon paper, no smearing or color change is observed. I would be interested to know if those who have found magenta tints on their prints can wipe them and observe this.

I have had excellent results using Konica Premium Silky paper with this printer (no smearing).

The only problem I observed, was that when printing multiple 13 x 19 photos, I saw a small smudge of black ink in the upper left hand corner on some prints. This disappeared when I took a break and resumed printing.

This is a class-act printer. Very quiet, and fast (compared to Epson). I will be buying one shortly, although I see that Canon may introduce some new printers this Fall with large format capabilities and new ink systems. I may just a while longer ....
summary: Black and White Printing Tips with the Canon i9900; Ink usage stats

I had one of these for over a year and it was the worst printer I have ever had or seen. Oh, it printed OK. Photo's look nice, fairly fast & easy to setup the wifi wireless connection. It's the ink consumption that ticks me off! I bought it because it has separate cartridges for each color thinking I could just replace what ever color ran out first. Wrong. First set of ink cartridges was gone in no time even though I hardly printed anything. Figured it was because they were the ones that came with it and HP was just being cheap by sending ink cartridges with it that were only half, or less, full. It wouldn't let me just replace the black and keep printing text pages either. No, it had to have all of them replaced. I bet I didn't get a dozen pages printed with it over a 3 to 4 month period and it was out of ink. ALL of the cartridges were empty! And I didn't even print a single photo, only text pages. I got one more set and put in it. This time I shut it down when I wasn't printing something. Didn't matter. Every time it was turned on it ran a full head cleaning cycle before it would print. I even put the extra large black cartridge in it but that didn't matter. It used the Photo Black for text printing. And guess what? In less than 4 months every cartridge was empty even though I only used it a few time to print something. Except for the extra large black, it was still over half full but the thing wouldn't print anything with the other ones empty. This is the first printer that I retired before it was actually broken. I wonder if it was intentional by HP to make money selling ink cartridges? After this one, I'm never buying another HP printer again.
summary: Worst printer ink addict ever, DO NOT BUY!

I received it today, and bought new ink (old ink can make your pen skip and get clogged).  I discovered the Pelikan is easier to write with than the Phileas, has a larger ink deposit than the Phileas converter, and the nib is just incredible.  It adapts to your hand immediately.  I don't think I'll ever buy another brand of fountain pen.  The Phileas may be more affordable, but the Pelikan is the result of superior workmanship

reviewText: I ordered this item as a way to save time when gluing intricate die cut designs on greeting cards.  After reading Amazon reviews where people who have purchased this item sing its' praises, I really thought I would be happy with it.  Didn't happen.  Since I'm in the middle of making Christmas cards, I had several intricate die cut designs all cut out, ready for the delivery of this miracle little machine.  With the first try, the die cut I used had good adhesive coverage, but when I peeled the design away from the backing, the glue absolutely did not pull away cleanly.  It looked like a mini Alien movie.  I thought maybe this happened because I didn't burnish the design before I peeled it off the backing, so I tried another design, then burnished it really well before I peeled it off.  Still horrible.  You could clearly see adhesive gunked in several places within the design, which looked really horrible when I attached the die to cardstock.  It's been a LONG time since I had to return an item, but this puppy is going back.  It probably works well enough for adhering a solid item, but it failed miserably for adhering intricate die cuts.  Really disappointed.
summary: Didn't work at ALL like I hoped it would!

I print a lot of copies for my writing and research work. I was using a basic laser printer, very cheap toner and so very user friendly to me. But it didn't have a lot of flexibility. I had to use another printer for scanning and copying, and have been looking for something to do double sided printing, so as to save paper.

This printer fit the bill perfectly. It was easy to set up and easy to use. This model doesn't have the wireless access of other models, but I didn't need that.  It can be networked, however, so that is enough for me.

It has a pretty small footprint for its capabilities.  Everything is tightly packaged and engineered so that there's no wasted space. It is very functional and works great in all of its capacities that I used it for.  It was my go to printer, the one that I used the most (I have about 4 other printers each with their own speciality).  This is an all around workhorse--not the best at any particular job, but competent at a lot. I even was able--in this day and age--to use the fax feature.  Had to fax a form to our insurance company.  Plugged it into the phone line, dialed the number, everything worked quickly, smoothly with absolutely no bumps.  This printer really is just plain easy to use.

My one complaint about the printer itself is that it's really surgey.  Meaning that when it turns on, it really draws in a lot of power. I couldn't plug it into my UPS because of that. It kept tripping the power circuit.  We have an old house and my office is an old add-on room off the side.  So the wiring isn't the best. When I turn this printer on, it has a tendency to trip the circuit breaker at times, and otherwise affect other things that are plugged in. I've not had that problem with other printers or devices.

Still, the bother was worth it to me. I liked this printer a lot. Note my use of the past tense.

The trouble I am now running into is not really one connected to the printer itself. But it radically affects my use of the printer.  I am a PhD student and adjunct professor. My home office budget, thus, is pretty bare bones.  While I need functional equipment, I can't pay the frankly outrageous prices charged for the manufacturer's stock toner.  I've long relied on other manufacturers who make generic brand toners and cartridges for my printeres.  So, when after printing about 1200+ pages the toner that this printer came with needed to be replaced and I looked on Amazon for generic substitutes. Found one, got it, installed it. The printer didn't recognize it. Called the company (Inkers). They were great, said I had the right model of cartridge, so they sent me another one. That one didn't work either (got refund quick by the company). Tried another brand.  Also didn't work. Cartridge fit, but the chip wasn't right. Tried a refill company. The replacement chip they sent also didn't work.

Meaning I can't find a cheaper generic toner for this printer and I can't quite get to paying the full toner price. So, for now, this printer sits unplugged and unused.

ADDED (April, 2013): First an update about the generic toner. They seem to have worked that out, so now I can print using the cheaper toner. However, I've run into another problem. If you're printing large amounts, this printer really starts slowing down. I'm printing out my dissertation, and when it hit 140 pages, it apparently overheats and prints five pages, stops for about 12 seconds, then prints another 5 pages, stops for 12 seconds.  So, this really makes printing out long documents extremely time consuming.  Given that I need to print out 5 copies of my 332 page dissertation, it means I really, really don't like this printer right now.
summary: Really like this printer except for one big caveat

I've tried other portable scanners before and have not been able to find something that is a) actually portable, b)scans well, c)light enough to lug around.

That said, I'm fairly happy with the Canon Scan-Tini for

a) it weighs about 2 lbs and does fit easily into my laptop bag

b) software is good for both Macs and PCs, easy to install. However, you can start scanning as soon as you plug the scanner up to a PC without installing drivers

c) nice card slot for scanning business cards; can also scan checks

d) accepts up to 20 sheets of paper and the scan results are clear. Scans fast for portable scanners - 15 pages per minute

e) scans receipts up to 39.4 inches long and the results are clear as well (I've had issues with scanning receipts on other scanners I've tried)

On the downside, there's no included AC adapter - in Canon's mind, that's an accessory - but I haven't really had the need for one. I'm perfectly fine with using just a USB.

reviewText: I love these pencils. They are a bit pricy but worth every penny. The lead is smooth and without the scratchy grains of most leads today. The erasers are superior as well. The grip is ergonomically pleasing. I can use them for hours with no fatigue. The over-all esthetic is beautiful and the colors are interesting. The only small design flaw for me is that, in my particular lighting situation, there is a spot on one side that catches light and reflects it brilliantly back into my eyes (there are silver metallic streaks along the barrel). It is simple enough to rotate the pen in my grip to remove the light hazard, though. Still, the overall beauty and function of this pen makes it a joy to use. Another great feature, though unadvertised, is that the top comes off, allowing you to refill the lead if you want (product does not come with extra lead.) If you are particular about your writing instruments, I believe you will love this pencil as much as I do. I've already ordered another set for future use.

reviewText:
For a small apartment this is a MUST HAVE! I am not allowed to hang any electronics or shelving on my apartment walls so mounting my TV & saving space would not be happening.

I noticed my friend in the apartment across from me had a stand she mounted her TV on and her living room seemed so much bigger than mine. I asked her for more information and she directed me to Amazon to find the one she bought.

While I could not find an exact copy of her stand I found a better one! This stand/cart has TWO shelving options, I knew this would be perfect for my apartment! I have a projector that I mounted to the top shelving unit (above the TV) and I use the bottom one to place my keyboard on when I am not using it. I love that I can lower my TV or raise it higher with the adjustable height system this cart provides.

The wheels are a nice touch, I can roll the cart anywhere I desire. I have my TV hooked up to my PC so I really never have a need to move it around but when I am cleaning I like that I can roll it out and vacuum underneath.

The main two bars do have a unnoticeable (if you are not looking for them) opening for cords to run through them instead of being outside and exposed. If all I had was a projector and a TV box (cable box) then those wires would fit perfectly fine in the bars and they would be out of sight. Since I have my TV hooked to my computer I do have multiple cords that would not fit but that is fine with me. The cart saves plenty of space by keeping the devices raised off of the ground and in one area.

The only small dislike I have is that the caps that cover the legs of the stand do come off often with little kids around playing on the floor. Once they seen that the caps can be removed they take them off any chance they can when I am not looking which exposes a not so kid friendly edge. I have hit my foot on it once and it was not fun. I am thinking about using a hot glue gun to hold them in place.

I love that I can lower my TV enough to see the projector image on the wall. This makes it easy for me to multitask and in my opinion is one of the best features!

Assembly was pretty simple when following the directions, although it did take about 45mins from gathering all the pieces and putting it together. The picture on the outside of the box made it easy to see what it was going to look like and gave me a nice reference to work off of. I am very happy with the quality of the materials, they do not feel cheap and I had everything that I needed to put the cart together in the box. The stand is sturdy and holds up well to all of the weight. 5/5 stars, very satisfied and I highly recommend! Discounted sample provided for evaluation and review.
summary: TV CART/STAND for Flat TV-(2) Shelving option, raise or lower the TV height, very adjustable-Space saving, great for Apartments!

This tape is wonderful.  It is strong, yet easily torn by hand.  It will tear in only one direction, perpendicular to its length, as one would expect.  So, no need for scissors or a sharp-edged dispenser when you want to tear off a length for sealing a package or large envelope for mailing.  Yet, it is strong - I tried to break it by stretching it lengthwise as well as along its width as hard as I could & it would not break.  I also tried to tear it lengthwise, and it would not tear in that direction.  So, despite its ease of tearing across its length when pulling some off of the roll, it will "do its job" keeping your package or large envelope sealed while in transit.  Finally, it is easy to "find" the end when stuck to itself on the roll & pull it up with a fingernail.  The folks at 3M have done it again!  Highly recommended...

reviewText:
The safe has an attractive gray metallic finish. The size is good, if you want a small safe to keep in a closet or other storage area. It comes with two keys which is convenient if you can't remember the combination. It's the perfect size for documents. It is heavy, about 40 pounds, so it's not very portable.

It is important to read the literature that comes with the safe. There are several cautions. The company does not recommend storing jewelry in the safe because of the high moisture content. Pearls are apt to suffer the worst, but clasps on necklaces and bracelets are also at risk. In fact, anything that could be damaged by the high moisture content should not be stored in the safe for any appreciable time.

I like the safe, but I was hoping to store jewelry in it while I was on vacation. This doesn't seem to be a practical idea. Still it's great for documents and other non-flammable articles.
summary: Attractive, Sturdy Safe May not Work for Jewelry

[I received both these and the 2"x2" labels. The labels are identical in every way except size, so my review for the 2"x2" labels is copied here.]

I own a small specialty foods store, and when we have fresh bread left over at the end of the day, we freeze it and sell it out of the freezer later. For months I've been looking for a way to label the individual bagged breads with the information we normally provide when we're selling it fresh -- bread name, price, ingredients, and baker info. All the labels I was able to find, though, either didn't hold up to being frozen, or couldn't be run through a printer. While these GHS labels are certainly overkill for my needs, since there's no other product on the market that does meet my needs, these are a godsend.

My questions upon first use were, 1) will they actually stick to the plastic bags?, and 2) do I really have to use a laser printer? The answers are both yes.

1. These labels *don't* stick well to plastic bags if the bags are some combination of cold/wet/not flat when the labels are applied, and for that reason they lose a star. They also take a few minutes to really adhere even in perfect conditions. So in order to get them to stick and stay stuck, I apply them to empty bags, smooth them out, wait a few minutes, and then put a loaf in the bag and put the whole thing in the freezer. I haven't done scientific testing of how long it takes for the stickers to really adhere, but within a few minutes I can still peel them off the bag; by the next day removing them would require ripping the bag.

2. I have a Canon inkjet printer at home, not one of the fancy inkjets they say might work with these. Some other reviewers say you can use an inkjet it just won't be waterproof, and I don't really need waterproof, so I thought I'd try it. I printed a sheet, let it sit in the tray for 20-30 minutes to dry, picked it up, touched the ink, and -- instant smudge. Everywhere. Even after 20-30 minutes to dry, these weren't not waterproof, they were just pools of ink sitting on top of the label. Had I been interested in getting ink all over my hands, I'm sure I could have wiped the labels practically clean. I have not had any issues with laser-printed labels smudging, so the answer is yes, you really really do need a laser printer for them!

Given that I'm not actually using them for chemicals, I haven't used the special Avery software for that purpose. I was able to find an Avery template for InDesign for 12-up 2"x2" stickers which worked great. My only alignment problems turned out to be user error, which disappeared once I realized I'd set my text boxes with asymmetrical margins. Oops.

Overall, I can vouch for the ability of these labels to adhere even at 0 deg F, and to remain smudge-free when used with a laser printer. If you have a need for those things, I don't know of any other easily available product that can meet that need.
summary: Works in the freezer, not in an inkjet

I was approached by Smart Weigh to see if I would be interested in providing a review for their product.  I agreed and they shipped the little scale to me.

The packaging was good, it was well protected from any shipping damage.  The box contained the following:
1.  The base scale
2.  The Display unit
3.  The power cable
4.  The connection cable for the display unit to the base scale

Nice features:
1.  The connection cable for the display unit allows you to move the display to different distances from the base scale to accommodate different size objects that you want to weigh.  This is an improvement over other scales that had the display attached to the base unit.
2.  You can change the display to show the following weights:
  a.  pounds
  b.  ounces
  c.  grams
3.  There is a "Tare" mode, this allows you to weigh the container separately to produce a tare weight.  Then when you place the packaged item on the scale it will adjust the weight to remove the "Tare" weight from the end result.
4.  You can use the scale in a location without electricity by turning on the unit using only the batteries.

I measured a multitude of items on the scale to see it's accuracy and was pleasantly surprised that this small scale weighed everything within very acceptable tolerances.  It was kind of fun to switch between modes to see what the different weights were.

One thing we found nice as that you could use this while cooking to measure the items that you need to add to a recipe.  So, let's say you need to add 6 ounces of chopped onions.  You can put the cutting board on the scale and take a "Tare" weight of the cutting board.  Then you can take it aside, chopped onions on it and place the cutting board back on the scale and weigh it in the ounces mode with it adjusting for the "Tare" weight of the cutting board.  So you can see if you have cut enough onion or to much.

This simple scale can be used in a small business to weigh packages, or it can be used at home for weighing packages or ingredients for a recipe or any other type of measurement you need.

Overall it is a smart design (thus the name Smart Weigh) and compact.  It can easily be stored back in it's box if you don't want it out all the time, and take practically no time to pull it out of the box and set up.

Oh, and I forgot to mention that you can calibrate the device so that if you have some tolerance issues because of atmosphere or altitude changes you can be sure the device is giving you accurate measurements no matter what.

Great little device and the price is wonderful (yes I got mine free, but I wouldn't be opposed to the price if I bought it).

Enjoy!

This is the handset for the AT&T DECT 6.0 Digital 2-Line Answering System (86109). Plusses: * The range is good. * AT&T handsets aren't continually transmitting radio signals through your brain while they're resting on the charging cradle (like the Panasonic DECT models do). Negatives: * Blue "charging" light on the handsets are as bright as a night-light, and there's no way to turn it off except by removing the handset from the charging cradle. * These handsets do not display time of day on the LCD display until you pick up a line. * There is no "message received" light on the handsets (unlike on Panasonic), you have to read the smallish LCD display (or enable annoying beeping on the base unit) to tell if you have messages. * The speakerphone in the handset isn't that good; the volume level goes up and down randomly (on all 5 of my handsets). * When a call is coming in, the screen doesn't indicate if the other line is already in-use (it would have been helpful to know if someone else in the house is able to pick up or if they're already on a call). * Extra button presses are required to select which phone directory to go through when making a call, even when there's only one directory.
summary: Poor handset speakerphone quality; bright blue LED lights up the room

I wanted to scan old negatives and slides.  This scanner does a very nice job.  It wanted something faster but could not afford it.  So I scan while doing other things.  I am very happy with the result.  I am saving money and getting results much more to my liking than by having my slides and negatives scanned by a service.  I am a power-user who is knowledgeable about photography, so this choice will not suit everyone.

Scanning of negatives and slides in high resolution (4800 dpi and higher) is slow, but you can't get faster without spending a lot more money.  The Digital Ice technology is a must for scanning slides and negatives and works VERY well.  I removes the appearance of dust without a negative impact on quality.  Don't scan slide or negatives without it.

I usually scan slides and negatives at 4800 DPI and that gives quite detailed images.  I scan to TIF format and then use a good photo editor to do corrections (exposure, cropping, color balance, resize) and export JPG format final versions in the 3-5 MP size range (but you can resize and compress to get smaller sizes if you want).  Then I delete the TIF files.

I have some 25 ISO Kodachrome slides which have a lot of fine detail, so I scan them at 6400 DPI which gives a very nice result, but it is slow and results in very large file sizes.  I crop or resize the 6400 DPI scans of 25 ISO Kodachrome slides to 30 MP images (6300 x 4725) or smaller.  I have not tried higher than that.  The detail in the scans at this high resolution is higher than I expected.

I would buy this scanner again.  I think that Epson makes the best scanners for my use.  I would not buy a less expensive Epson scanner than the v500 for my use.  If my pockets were deeper I would opt for something a little faster.
If you want 4x6" prints, using paper that size will save a lot of hassle compared to trying to get your software to  reasonably lay out multiple 4x6's on an 8.5x11 sheet, then trying to cut them out.

We got this all-in-one printer and have enjoyed it so far.  We have always bought HP printers and have had an HP all-in-one for years.  When I had the chance to get this printer, I took the chance since the HP is getting older.  It still works fine, but is simply old technology.  And, I wanted to try a printer made by a company other than HP.

This printer was relatively easy to set up.  If we had done it right the first time, it would have been very easy, but we didn't follow instructions and had to go back and figure out how to get back to the beginning.  It wasn't too hard and it got done.  We set it up in the office in the back of the house while the laptop we use is in the front of the house in the family room.  The wireless capability is great and it's really nice to print things and go pick them up when it's convenient. The speed seems to be faster than our old printer and the printouts look really nice.  The color is bright and crisp.

So far, I recommend this printer without reservation.  I look forward to using it more in the coming weeks.
summary: Efficient and easy to use printer

I purchased this journal on the recommendation of a blogger. I use fountain pens to journal and paper quality varies widely. The blogger thought that the 90W paper would do a good job holding the ink, and it does. I use non-standard colors and they all popped on this not-quite-white paper. I don't have much use for the elastic nor the pocket on the inside back cover. I also thought the ribbon bookmark felt cheap. However, I loved journaling in the book and will buy another when I am in need. I really like the crazy orange color.

My wife is a teacher and with the HP instant ink it's an amazing deal.  Ink is so expensive and she prints so much material for her classroom that the amount we pay is worth every penny.

She prints on cardstock (pretty thick) and regular paper and the results are very acceptable.

Printing photos is a different story though.  I thought it would be fun to try to print a few photos on high quality paper, big mistake.  First problem is it took me 4 prints to get the colors right.  I have a color correct monitor for photo editing, and the picture is perfect there.  I had to make it excessively yellow and unsaturated to get an acceptable print.  Also once printed, even after 24 hours, the ink gets all over your fingers.  HP would probably blame the paper, but I have used that exact same paper on my professional photo printer and there is no smudging seconds after the image comes out of the printer.  The problem is the ink, not the paper.

Amazing printer for non-photo work.  Stay away if you're printing photos though.

Another tip, if you're using a Mac - DO NOT USE ADOBE READER to print PDFs.  Adobe Reader is the worst software ever created.  My wife was having problems where the printer wasn't centering pages, and we even called HP support.  After a lot of research I kept finding clues that the Adobe Reader software was problematic, so we did a test.  I opened the PDF in the built in Mac PDF reader "Preview" and in Adobe.  It printed perfectly from Preview, and badly from Adobe.  Problem solved.  I uninstalled Adobe Reader and we will never install again.
summary: Excellent printer for teachers, terrible for photos

I am a very thorough and picky shopper. I have had two crosscut shedders in the past, one was
fellows. The last one lasted about eight years, then took a dump. I wanted a micro shredder this
time, both for added security and to not have to empty the bun as often as a crosscut machine. I
bought this Amazon Basics micro cut shredder with a bit of skepticism. Boy was I wrong I
have had it for a month, and put it through its paces It sheds twelve sheets of 20 lb. paper without
so much as the motor straining a little. The micro cut pieces push down very easily so I don't
have to empty so often .. Press down is not the right term. I tap the bin on the floor and they
micro pieces condense to the bottom. In short, I LOVE this s shredder. And I am not easily
impressed with machines. If you need new shedder, I very strongly recommend this one. And the
price is right.
summary: The micro cut pieces push down very easily so I don't have to empty so often

Like most people I accumulated a lot of paper, and also like a lot of other people, decided that it was time to get rid of everything I did not absolutely need. I wanted a scanner that could handle the backlog, but could then be used for maintenance. This Swingline product was an Amazon special the day I went looking so I decided to give it a try. I have been mostly happy with it, with a couple of complaints.

First of all, the 25 page feeder works as advertised as long as:
  -no pages are stapled together
  -the pages are all more or less the same size
  -the feeder is not over-filled

If there are pages stapled together, or if there is a random small piece of paper (such as a receipt) mixed in, then it will probably end up jamming. Clearing jams is not a big deal most of the time, but it does detract a bit from the value of having an auto feeder. these complaints aside, the auto feeder did save me a lot of time. I grabbed stacks of paper, placed them in the tray and walked away. Ten minutes later I came back and put some more in. Every 2-3 rounds I emptied the bin with the shredded paper and kept going. I went through dozens of batches over 4 days and by the time I was done I had filled 8 garbage bags of shredded paper, which I dutifully recycled.

The top chute allows you to take care of stapled pages, credit cards, non-standard-sized- items, etc. In fact the top chute is what I mostly use nowadays. It's powerful enough to handle a few pages at once.

The cross-cut functionality is essential in ensuring data security today, and this device makes reasonable small pieces. I feed bills in diagonally so that I can be reasonably sure that no piece ends up with a complete account number.

it's quiet enough while operating - certainly quieter than the older shredder I owned previously.

bottom line - I recommend this for people looking to clear up their backlog of paper documents and don't want to stand around all day feeding documents by hand into a shredder.
summary: Very good shredder but the auto feeder does jam when it runs into anything non-standard

Reading some reviews here, I see that some people make the mistake of assuming that any glue or cement should suit all purposes.  In fact, most glues are best suited for specific purposes; that is why there are so many different kinds.

Rubber cement is unique in a few ways.  It is not water based; that is evident as soon as you open the jar.  It smells of an organic solvent.  You don't want to breathe in a lot of that.  Best to use it in a ventilated area.

In the name of the product is what it excels at: "no wrinkle".  The solvent in it causes the cement to reduce in volume as it dries, that is, it shrinks, so it makes a snug fit.

It is especially well suited to gluing fairly flexible things - like paper or foil - to many other things, like paper, foil, plastic, wood, metal, etc.  The solvent could be reactive to some things, making it unsuitable for some materials.  Items glued down with rubber cement can often be peeled away even after the glue has dried; the glue can usually be rubbed off.  On some porous substances (some kinds of paper) the glue could soak in and change the color.

It may also be suited for fixing items together in a temporary fashion, in which case the glue can often be rubbed off.  But when attached to rigid materials and especially when protected (e.g. covered with a laminate) it is reasonably permanent.

Because it is not water soluble, it might be handy for joining things that need to stay stuck while immersed in water.

It is used a lot by all kinds of crafts.  I like to print templates or labels designed on the computer, then trim them with scissors or a paper cutter, then use rubber cement to attach it to metal, plastic, or wood.  Then I take it down to the shop and use the printed guides to cut or drill.  I can also overlay the result with clear laminate to have a permanent, protected and professional-looking panel, for example in electronics projects.

Rubber cement is not especially well suited to joining hard things to other hard things - materials like plastic, wood, metal, and so on - except for temporary purposes, in which case it can be very handy if you need to separate them later and remove the glue.  For example, to cut sheet aluminum, I may glue plywood to both sides with rubber cement for more rigidity, cut it, then remove the plywood.

Last, chemical interactions with old-style (pre-digital) photographs could potentially fade the photographic image with time; this may apply to other kinds of printed material with time as well.
summary: Special-purpose cement excels for some purposes, unsuitable for others

Do you know someone whos obsessed with the song, I Like to Move It; you know, the song that hit the top 100 charts in 1994? Its a song by Reel 2 Real (Erick Morillo) featuring ragga vocals by rapper The Mad Stuntman (Mark Quashie). Well, if you do know someone like that, and that special someone also has a birthday coming up, then this will be absolutely perfect! That person will laugh themselves silly over the crazy chicken moving it to the beat.

However, if you plan to send this to anyone who may not know that song, then forget it! For them, this card will neither be funny nor intelligible. It will fall flatter than a pancake.

I was born a couple of generations too early for this song to be part of my music culture. I didn't know it. When I opened the card and heard it for the first time, it sounded like unintelligible racket. I listened to it at least a dozen times. It never got clearer. Each time I heard not one word that was understandableand with the poor quality of the card music systemhonestlyit sounded like noise. Even the beat was unpleasant.

But then I investigated the songand everything changed!

The back of the card told me what song it was supposed to be. I listened to parts of it on the Internet. I watched a few music videos featuring the song. It didn't take long before I got hookedand Im saying this as a classical-music-loving 69-year-old woman. Yes, I started to love that song. It stuck in my ear like an earworm and I kept wanting to move it (i.e., the lower parts of my body) to the beat.

I could definitely understand why some folks would get this song planted in their heads obsessively. What a crazy fun song with a contagious dance beat!

Well, after all that, I listened to the card again, and finally got it! I understood every word, appreciated the beat, and laughed at the chicken. My brain knew the song and filled in for what the card lacked in music quality.

So the lesson is: this card is perfect for someone who you already know loves this song (probably someone born in the 1970s). But if you're not sure, buy another card.

One final piece of advice: if you're willing to spend the extra bucks to buy a music card, its a good idea to buy it on Amazon. They don't cost any less in the store; I checked it out. Why? If you buy it from Amazon, youll be sure that the cards battery is 100% fresh, not worn down my countless people trying it out in the store before deciding not to buy it.

My card arrived in perfect condition in a big padded envelope.

[I received a complimentary version of this card in exchange for an honest review. ]
summary: Gotta know and love the song then the card will be perfect

They told me they couldn't instantly send me another part unless I would give them my credit card number so they could old back $50 till such a time as I return the defective product.  They wouldn't accept a debit card with mastercard logo only a true credit card.  Lexmark never required this when I had one of there printers though their was other issues going on there.

I was glad that I didn't go this route because brother would only give me the body of the printer not a brand new one even though it was basically a D.O.A. right from the start. I returned it to amazon for a brand new one with no hassle free so Kudso to amazon for that.

I did an exchange of the printer and the new one was not defective so that was a good thing below is a list of pros and cons.

PRO:

1. It is one of the fastest printers for the price range
2. The ink is one of the cheapest out there.
3. It can duplex and scan duplex.

CONS:

1. When printing a large quantity of duplexing sheets it skips either one side or spits out blank pieces of paper.  I had this happen to 15 of my sheets of paper.
2. When the fax decides to take control or there is a jam it won't let you simply turn off the printer until the problem is resolved instead it just says busy and you have to to physically unplug the printer and plug it back in to have it usable again.
3.  When using non standard paper there is no option to use a custom setting.  While you can use custom paper it is very limited and not intuitive.  For example for me to successfully print onto a 9X12 piece of paper I was told it would only accept it from the back feeder and even then it seemed to only work when you went into settings and said fit to page.  Even with this option selected it would not work if you were putting it in the front trays.
4. The trays seemed a bit flimsy and letter paper would only work if they were put in the tray the long way (landscape) instead of the short way.  Other printers capable of handling two trays that are wide format can accept both letter and tabloid paper going the same direction (i.e. Epson workforce 7620).

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Because of the fact the brother would skip on either one side or both sides every so often when doing a large print job that was in duplexing mode, and because jams forced you to unplug the printer to clear it (even when there really was no jam or the printer still decided it was jammed when the jam was removed), and because custom paper was non intuitive and could only be accepted from the back feeder I gave it a two stars instead of 4 or 5.

Suffice it to say I opted to return this printer for a full refund and used that refunded money to purchase an Epson workforce 7620.  While the speeds aren't quite as fast as the brother (especially using color printing) and while the ink is a bit more expensive the trade off of better quality prints, more intuitive screens, not having to rotate paper based on size in the printer tray, and I would assume paper will not skip when doing large print jobs (though I will only know this for sure when I do my next newsletter on it which requires lots of duplexed copies) for these reasons I would highly recommend that you ditch this printer and opt for the Epson workforce 7620 as compatible ink is reasonable and all around it seems like a better quality, more sturdy printer all around.

Thanks, Amazon for your quick turn around time for printer replacements and for your willingness to ship the printer before you get the returned product (WITHOUT HOLDING MONEY CAPTIVE TILL THE BAD PRINTER IS RETUREND) HINT HINT BROTHER CUSTOMER SUPPORT !!!.

Anyway I love amazon but do not like this printer or brothers return policy, I don't know what Epsons return policy is but I would guess it is more friendly than brothers.
summary: I was glad that I didn't go this route because brother would ...

reviewText: Very well constructed! Nothing "flimsy" about it. Came packaged in flat position.....ready to use!

There are indentations for wrists, but they are about 3 inches too far apart to be useful for proper typing. This spacing forces the pad to be aligned with the center of the pad at the space bar. This is bad because the pad does not line up to the keyboard, and wastes room on keyboard trays. You will need to extend the pad about 2 inches to the left of the keyboard. On a standard keyboard you will then have ~ 2 inches of unused space by the numpad. On a 10-keyless, it will extend the keyboard about 2 inches on each side. There is also an annoying crunching sound when touched (probably because the gel insert has some kind of plastic wrapping around it inside). For gaming, it doesn't really matter because you only use WASD and perhaps numpad/arrows, so it can be moved to the right for this task.

The 3m product at 18-19 inches would be better, as it doesn't make noise, has a rubber exterior which is easier to clean, is much softer, and doesn't have any contour.
Would be nice if this was scaled down to work on a 10-keyless setup.

Edit:
I noticed that the bottom seam comes apart (it's just adhesive holding it together), and there is a sort of plastic membrane wrapped around a bunch of white gel/glue like stuff. It doesn't seem too ooze out though. The 3M pads will ooze if there is even a small hole. I'm going to try a foam pad instead, since they can't leak or break down.
summary: Not good for typing, acceptable for gaming

reviewText: This is a good value in a laptop stand. Once the height adjustment is in place, it feels solid and reliable. However, changing the height adjustment requires removing the laptop for safety and to be able to use both hands on the mechanism. Also, the two raised pieces of metal at the bottom, whose purpose is to prevent the laptop sliding down off the stand, are so high that they cut into your wrist as you use the laptop. The trick I used to deal with this problem was to put a foam sheet under the laptop to raise it up to the point where the two raised pieces were no longer an issue. I realize that this is a generic stand and that laptops come in all thicknesses but I still think the supports could have been made lower and possibly even padded.
summary: A good value in a laptop stand

I use this machine to organize my office papers, customer reports, tax reports, etc into attractive notebooks that are easier to store or mail. So far it's been a dream to own. After adding up the cost of purchasing comb bound notebooks printed at Staples and OfficeMax, it just made sense to buy the machine and do it myself. 100 pages bound in a notebook costs over $50 each from these stores. For less than the price of 2 books, I can own the binding machine, purchase a 100 pack of combs (Fellowes Plastic Comb Bindings, 0.5 Inch, Black, 90-Sheet Capacity, 100 per Pack (52326) or Fellowes Plastic Comb Bindings, 1 Inch, 200-Sheet Capacity, Black, 10 per Pack (52383) or Fellowes Plastic Comb Bindings, 0.5 Inch, Black, 90-Sheet Capacity, 100 per Pack (52326)), and a 500 sheet ream of paper. Two notebooks from these stores and I've already spent more than the machine?!?! This Pulsar Plus 150 is a well made machine. The punching handle extends over the entire machine. I can punch paper from any location around the unit. The punching is smooth and doesn't require much muscle at all. Just follow the instructions: insert the sheets of paper to punch the holes (up to 10-12 sheets), then insert the comb plastic and all the sheets you wish to bind (up to 150). This is all very quick and easy. I could print and bind my notebooks in less time that it would take me to drive to Staples to pick up my order. In my work, I need to make my workbooks and presentations look professional. I have been using Fellowes Transparent PVC Binding Covers, Letter, 100 pack (52089). These covers can be punched with the Pulsar and bound with the combs. I found the placing the plastic cover in the middle of a stack of 6 sheets of paper gives me the best punch through. Punching the PVC sheet alone sometimes creates wrinkles in the PVC. In the notebooks, I use 1 Transparent Cover on the front and a thicker black (or colored) sheet of art paper for the back cover.
summary: Great investment for a home office.  Organize paper, reports, taxes...

I have used and loved Parker Jotter pens for years. I especially love the pink Jotter and have had a number of them, which eventually get lost. So I ordered a few more recently. I was really disappointed when one of them started having trouble "clicking" open and closed. I unscrewed the pen and found the inside of the barrel filled with ink. What a mess! I refuse to put it in my purse...just leave it on my desk. It still works, and so far the ink hasn't leaked out of the pen, but I can't click it open and closed easily. It's all gummed up inside. So I ordered another for my purse. Guess what! Now, it's leaking, too! Barrel full of ink. Luckily, it didn't leak out into my purse. Boy, would I have been mad. What gives, Parker? Really disappointed!!! I want to give this pen five stars, and I would if it didn't leak, but as it is, it's a dud.

UPDATE: I contacted Parker, and they very cheerfully offered to replace my two pens. They said their ink refills have a shelf-life and surmised that these pens may have been old. They didn't have any pink pens in stock, so they let me choose an alternate color. I am extremely pleased with the way Parker handled my problem.

UPDATE: 2015: I've discovered that if you store these pens with the colored barrel end UP, they will begin to leak. I surmise that the original seller had the box of pens upside down for a while, which caused the leakage, as there were several of us who had this problem. So I think my leaky pen was just a fluke.

Two weeks ago my third Palm in six years broke down. The first one was my own fault, I dropped it on the floor and the display cracked. The second one was a Tungsten E which lasted a little less than 2 years. Then it started to behave erratically, leading to a complete breakdown. Because I assumed it was some bad luck I experienced, I purchased another Palm, this time a Tungsten 2E. It has functioned for about 2 years, then when I wanted to switch it on, it remained black. Dead.

I loved the functionality, and I am really helpless without the hundreds of contacts, my to-do list and my agenda. But a PDA has to be reliable.

The Tungsten doesn't come exactly cheap either. What happened to the price? As far as I can recall, the last Tungsten I bought for $200,- or so. Factory new, not refurbished. Now I have to pay over $400 for something which typically breaks down within two years? Is this a joke or so?
summary: Functionality is good -- before it breaks down

I was surprised at how well this Lang coloring book is constructed; however, I was not surprised at all by how cute the designs were. I have seen Susan Winget's designs in household goods and needlework for years and was really happy to find a coloring book filled to the brim with her designs. The book is called Doodle House and it appears to be a glimpse at Ms. Winget's sketchbook. The designs are hand-drawn and have the charming less than perfect look I expect from hand-drawn. I think that it makes coloring them more interesting and I am enjoying this book quite a bit. Two things that I really like about the construction of the book are the spiral binding and the hard covers. The binding makes it easy to open the book to a flat position for coloring. It also makes it easy for leftys to color with the same easy as rightys. The hardcover gives a good flat surface for coloring on the go. There are many designs with sayings as well as birds, animals and flowers. While it is not a book dedicated to the natural world, many of the designs lean that way. The designs are quite detailed but not what I would call intricate with tiny spots to color. As I mentioned previously, the hand-drawn nature of the artwork does show less than perfect. There are disconnected lines, a bit of uneven spacing, and even lines of varying thickness. It is that which gives it the sketchbook quality. This is what I found while coloring in this book and testing my coloring medium on the paper: 100 Design pages featuring hand-drawn artwork by Susan Winget with a focus on nature Designs are printed on one side of the page Paper is medium weight, white, slightly rough and perforated Designs do cross over the perforations but stop short of the spiral binding. If you remove pages from the book, the edge that you will lose does not contain essential elements of the design. Spiral Binding with hard covers that help the book lay flat and provide a good coloring table Alcohol-based markers bled through the paper lightly. I was surprised at how little bled through given that the paper is more medium in weight. I would still use a blotter of card stock to protect the designs below my working page when using these style of markers. Water-based markers, gel pens and India ink pens did not bleed through or leave shadows on the back of the page. Colored pencils worked well with this paper. It has a good tooth and allowed for applying layers of the same color to get rich pigment. I could also layer multiple colors well and I could blend both oil and wax based pencils easily with a pencil style blending stick.
summary: 100 coloring pages with Susan Winget's cute style  printed one side of the page
