reviewText:
High marks to Uniden for giving us the best of both worlds:  A corded desktop/wall mount corded phone and 2 cordless handsets.  I didn't realize previously it was possible to have both.

One big advantage of this phone package over the cordless phones that my sons have is that when their power goes out, so does their phone service.  However, with the D1788-2, this is not the case.  Even if there is no power you can still make phone calls using the base set.  That's a huge plus for anyone who lives where there are occasional power outages due to falling tree limbs, storms, or general power failure.

You can also dial in to your answering system from any touch phone when away from home after programming the phone with a security code of your choosing.

Not much to do to prepare the phones for use.  Plug the base set into an AC electrical outlet using the provided adapter and to a telephone jack using the provided cord and attach the handset to the base with the provided cord; put the provided rechargeable batteries in the charging units for the two cordless phones and plug the chargers into electrical outlets using the provided cords.  Now the phones are ready to use as well as to program following the menu in the users guide.

Pretty much intuitive, but good instructions are in the manual.

Programming the phone is not difficult.  You have the choice of programming each phone separately or by clicking on the global menu option to program all 3 phones with date and time, etc, at the same time.

The user guide that comes with the phone is relatively small.  If you prefer something larger, google Uniden D1788 User Guide and you will get a larger PDF version which you can print or read on your computer monitor.  I found it easier to use this version to focus on what I was trying to accomplish.

The phones are good looking, especially the base phone.

The Uniden D1788-2 is a good wireless phone package at a good price.  I recommend it.
summary: Great Value; 3 Fine Phones For A Good Price

My wrist used to hurt - I code for a living. I was in my mid twenties when the weight of my hands on the desk, or flat mouse surface produced notable discomfort. I changed to a gel pad mouse pad in 2006, and that's all I've used since. So I have some experience with these types of mouse pads.

reviewText: its a note book that does the job

Although it is extremely handy to have my books I am typing out of on this copy holder, I found two major flaws with it.

The first was the sheer amount of space it took up. I found it very ungainly, a pain to move around, and it simply took up way too much space. I couldn't fit it under my computer screen like it advertised and can't imagine it working that way unless your screen could go very high.  So I have it off to the side of my screen; which is less than ideal but works.

The second thing that really annoyed me was when I tried to turn the pages. There is a lip on the front of the black base that prevented me from turning the pages easily.  I had to physically lift up the book and turn the pages so that they wouldn't scrape and start to tear on the lip. You wouldn't run into this issue if you are using loose-sheet pages instead of a book like I was, so it depends on what you are planning on using this for.

That being said, there are some really great things about this. I love how the legs can pivot so you can stand it up straight or you can lean the book back. That was a REALLY nice feature.  I also loved how you could move it up and down and at basically any level that you wanted. That was another huge plus.  Really, if they had just made the lip in the front fold-able and if it took up a bit less room on the desk I would be VERY happy with it!

reviewText: I am a professional artist and I have used this pen for the past 5 years to ink my art. This is by far the best gel pen on the market (and I've tried MANY). Very smooth ink, never skips and it takes under 30 seconds to dry. It will smear if you touch it or brush the page immediately after writing with it, but there's a simple solution to that: Wait a few seconds before you touch the page! My scanner picks this ink up well, the lines are nice and very smooth and in my experience it is better than most artist inks, including India ink (which is very expensive, runs and stains like crazy). Aside from art, this is my preferred writing pen as well, I write with it daily. It is very comfortable to hold, won't dry when you forget the top off and one pen will last a fairly long time compared to others I've used. No problems with it bleeding through the page, either. A bit expensive, but you get what you pay for and for the performance these are worth the price! I really can't live without these pens and I hope they don't change them, they are the best!

The ergonomically styled modern look is a small part of the attraction for me. This pen balances nicely in my hand [large] and writes smoothly on any paper without skipping. I am completely satisfied with this pen. I've tried it with EF, 1.5mm and 1.9mm stubs and they all work perfectly! I hope to buy another in the future.
Just what I was looking for and shipping was quick!

reviewText:
Uni-ball AIR rollerball pens  write smoothly, and the colors that we tried (black, blue, and red) are true and fairly saturated. The pens are light and small. They have the feel of a lightweight fountain pen. A 0.7mm rollerball writes a medium line and gives some room for variations in thickness, so if you have a somewhat calligraphic hand, or you want to be able to draw with flourishes, they will accomodate that fairly well.

The claim that they write at any angle is technically true, but the lines lose some fluidity when writing upside-down. Still, most pens won't do that at all, so the Uniball is still ahead.

Thicker lines smudge easily within a minute or so of writing, but are well fixed on the page after that. The ink does not smear from incidental wetness. We can't say much about the durability of the ink or the pen, of course.

Overall, a pleasant and effective writing experience. Four stars.

This has been so much fun! Whenever I get anything digital, I always worry I won't be able to figure it out, but this is really easy to use. You can use it as-is or put in your own memory card, which is what I like to do. Then you turn it on, you choose what kind of film it is (slide, negative, 35mm, etc.), then you decide if you want to save it. It's that easy. There are other otpions and I need to read the instructions more, but I've been perfectly happy with what I've been doing so far. It also will flip the image over (if you put the negative or slide in upside down or backwards). It's really handy and very simple to get the hang of it.

Then after I copied several pictures, I took the memory card out and put it in the little device I have to transfer it into my computer and played with the photos in Picasa (which you can google and download for free - for anyone who doesn't have Photoshop or anything like that), and I really had fun cropping and brightening old photos.

In the past when I used to always use a 35mm camera, as it got older it did not always take the best pictures. And sometimes when I would get a roll of film developed I would notice a picture in the negatives that they didn't print for me. I asked them once why that happens and they said it was because maybe the picture was too dark, or perhaphs over-exposed and too bright and it wouldn't come out good. But now with this device I can go and see what those "lost" photos are like. I have to say, I have been finding quite a few that to me definitely are worth having. Just because someone at the photo booth didn't think it was worth it doesn't mean it isn't a picture I would want. I put 2 examples above in the images near the product image if you want to see what I mean.

One picture was at the end of the roll and you can see where the film was ending and getting light exposure or whatever when it was time to take the film out of the camera. But these days with digital technology it was so easy for me to crop off the top of the picture and then just tweak the light a little to make it a little better quality. It's not the best photo as far as quality goes, but this brings back a memory of this day that I had forgotten, and I just love that.

The other picture they never developed for me is one that I am so happy to have. I had never seen this before and if I didn't have this Wolverine Converter, I would never have known this was on my negatives. Again, it seems a bit over-exposed, but I am so happy to have this. Our cat recently passed away, at 17 years old, and seeing this picture of him when he and my daughter were both younger just makes me smile. And to think, I would have missed this totally just because the person who developed my film thought it was not worth developing.

I eventually stopped using my old 35 mm camera and now I have a digital one. But all the boxes of old pics I have, I can now take the negatives and check them out to see if there are any surprise photos like these or sometimes you give pictures away even though you don't have doubles, and then you just forget about it. So this is a fun and very handy item to have. So often I would want to get copies of pictures made, but just never bother. Now I can do it whenever I want.

The only down side of this converter to me was that the cord is so short. I had to get an extension cord to use it. But I am enjoying using it so much that the cord is not too much of an issue. So I have to give this five stars because I love photos and memories and this really has been great. Now to get some old slides from my mother-in-law to get some pics of my husband when he was little. It's like all these memories that would otherwise just be lost are now right at our fingertips. Things like that just really make me so excited and happy. If you are like that too, then you will really be happy with this converter.

P.S. I have tried uploading the cropped and fixed versions of my 2 photos a few times, but for some reason, they are just not showing up. But the original photos stright from the negatives are there.

This is a basic bulletin board set that would be perfect for a child's room, dorm room, class room, home, office or any place that you need a board to keep up with all those little sticky notes, paper items, cards and photos. The blue material backing was heavy duty and had a tight weave burlap feel to it. The edges of the board of made of lightweight aluminum so there won't be a lot of weight on the wall when it is hanging up. The board comes with 5 multi colored push pins and 5 multi colored thumb tacks. The product features two sliding hooks at the top to mount it with and I love that they will adjust to where you need them to and are not stuck into one position. I like the extra thought put into the designing of this board, one of my favorite features it the rounded corners made of plastic instead of the metal. The company or designer was really looking out for our young ones with that design feature. The back of the board is metal however it's too far from the front to be magnetic. The only negative issue I have with it is that the description states that it's 16x12, the instructions in the box state that it is 15.8" x 11.8". I measured it in the video and you can see for yourself the actual size if you are in question about that before purchasing. Overall this is a very nice bulletin board for small spaces and is offered at a decent price considering the quality and extra effort put into designing it. Considering the only issue I can find is a discrepancy in description size I'm giving it a solid 5 Stars. *A sample of this product was provided to me free for testing and review. No promise was made for a positive review.

reviewText:
I actually expected to NOT be that enthralled with this printer, I owned several Epson letter-sized inkjets from 2000-2008 and got fed up with the cheesy paper handling, the BUGGY driver installation that didn;t recognize your printer half the time, and worst of all, the clogging heads. I spent more time than necessary back then cleaning and soaking nozzles to try and get the things to print. I made my switch to Canon and never looked back until this came along.

So I've been using it daily, hammering away, and its been nothing short of amazing, especially in the paper handling area. Clean printing, fast outout that still looks sharp (draft mode used to be a JOKE with Epson), and a mechanically driven moving paper deck for DOUBLE SIDED PRINTING THAT IS FLAWLESS. I'm not kidding. I didn't expect that and I had actually wondered why this printer was up there in price when you can easily get AIO's for 89 bucks. The motorized paper handling deck works very well, and looks totally cool while it's "performing", lol.

The copy machine part also performed pretty near perfect. I copied several documents for my guitar students and almost couldn't tell the two apart. I don't use the fax segment, but both copy and fax are really a scan and then execute an output so there's no reason faxing should noty look good.

Photo printing: Canon added a very good feature that you see usually on the higher-end pro photo printers: besides the standard Cyan, Magenta, Yellow and Black cartridges, they included a Photo Black to handle certain types of photo paper media. Nice. I have that in my pro non-Epson 13x19 photo printers but to see it here makes this quite a viable unit to hammer out 4x6's to 8x10's.

OK, last but very cool feature: device printing. I keep this printer connected to my PC at work, don't want it on the main wireless network nor do I want to share it. But I want to be able to print from my iPhone and iPad. Asking too much? NOPE, not with this unit. It creates its own wireless network and therefore you can print directly to it (I assume that means Android also, just have no way to test that). The LCD on the printer is a flip up color screen with menus to set everything up including the AirPrint network, or even print direct from your memory cards. Speaking of setting up, the driver and app software was an easy download from Epson's site, and it actually WORKED, quickly at that.

Oh, one more feature! This unit also does CD/DVD printing. I'm starting to think this printer is capable of writing my uncle in the Navy...

Often when someone wants a home office AIO I steer them to Canons because I had given up years ago on Epson. But things have changed and the local wireless AirPrint network and the motorized dual-sided printing (and small footprint) makes this a new favorite. I use it everyday at work and it's been flawless.
summary: WAY Better Than I Expected, Great iOS/Android Printing Support

The good porcelain chalkboards had deep chalk holders in which the erasers could be laid flat.  This chalkboard is the perfect size for an announcement board or a board to put in the front of a store, but the chalk holder cannot come off, and those types of boards usually don't have chalk holders attached so customers won't write on the board.  It wipes nicely with water, after being erased.  It doesn't erase as well as "fake" chalkboards, but it erases fine.  My main problem was how hard it was to mount it.  This board took me more than an hour to mount.  It is very hard to calculate where the screw holes should go on the wall, plus you have to drill your own holes in the aluminum frame, which is hard, and can damage the porcelain.  Just as long as you can mount this board correctly, you should be fine.  If you don't mount it correctly (which is easy to do), every time you write on it, the board will shake.

Quite unlike some junk pens I purchased a while back, these are free-flowing without the need to jump start them so to speak. I just popped the cap off and began to write. I do love the variety of color and one household member quipped, I didn't know there were so many colors.

Each set comes packaged in four separate trays, a dozen in each. When I was finished working (more like playing) with them, each pen nestled back into the tray easily. Im in the process of scouting out more permanent storage for them, but I do intend to keep them in the plastic trays.

I used to have a craft box set up for my son, specifically for those rainy and sick days.  These would be perfect for an activity / craft box for an older child and yes, for the adult coloring crowd.  Very nice quality pens at a very good price point of around $20 at this point in time.

Sample provided for review.

reviewText: I just can't see where these are any better than the same design from other companies at about 1/2 the price. Kohinoor makes quality products but the names costing too much in this case

This is a 3 part review. The first is to rate the product for it's quality and how it was intended to be used (card collecting). The second part is for those of you looking to organize your coupons or craft/jewelry items. The third part is a warning about different kinds of plastics and the importance of choosing the right kind. USING THESE 9 POCKET PAGES AS HOLDER FOR CARDS & COLLECTIBLES: I've worked in the antiques and collectible business for many years and Ultra Pro is the product all professionals and serious collectors use. They have different grades of pages, "Silver" (this item) being one of the better ones, specifically because it is "non-pvc" plastic (acid free). But all of Ultra Pro's products and pages hold up to regular use and are high quality. Ultra Pro's Platinum Card Game Supplies Ultra Pro 100 Nine-Pocket Pages is slightly better (and more expensive) only because the plastic is a little thicker. If you don't plan on taking the items in and out of the page over and over and over then Silver is all you need. Although the description of this item states "card game supplies", 9 pocket top load pages are perfect for housing collectible trading cards of all kinds, including traditional sports cards (baseball, football, hockey, etc). Also good for Pokmon and similar cards. ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ USING THESE 9 POCKET PAGES FOR COUPONING, JEWELRY & CRAFT ITEMS: I tried using these pages to hold my coupons in a binder. I found the 9 pocket pages not to be practical for this. The reason is the pockets are a bit small for quick picking and gathering of coupons. When I want to get my coupons I don't want to have to struggle to get them. These pockets are made "tight" on purpose so the collectible cards don't easily fall out. Well, that "tight" fit also keeps your coupons in tight, and I found that makes them hard to retrieve easily and quickly. Also, most coupons are much larger than the cards these pages were made for, so if you want to put a coupon in the pocket you often have to fold the coupon. When you fold your coupon you cannot see all of the info on the coupon at a quick glance. And as any good couponer knows, accessing/picking, gathering, storing, and assessing/viewing your coupons quickly is important. I find the same problem when I tried to use these 9 pocket pages for small craft items and jewelry. I once tried to use these pockets so I cold display jewelry items in a binder, but it did not go well. If the item is something a bit bulky (like a piece of jewelry or crafting parts) then the "tightness" of the pocket (intended to keep cards from falling out) creates a problem holding jewelry and tiny craft parts. Although if you're going to house jewelry or craft items long term you really do want the non-pvc archival quality pockets. You just need to realize this size pocket is intended to hold one or two thin cardboard cards only, it really isn't intended for larger or thicker items. The pages will hold up, but the item (thicker or uneven craft item or jewelry) may not lay properly or fit well in the pocket. For bulky items with odd shapes you should consider using hard plastic boxes. Make SURE they are the clear hard plastic type, not the pliable milky or opaque plastic because the milky or opaque usually are not archival qualit and are not good for long term storage, regardless of what they are marketed to be used for. How can you tell the difference? One way is to push on the box. If it has any give to it at all it most likely is not archival quality and is not to be used for long term storage for ANY item. If it is very hard, with no give, and is very clear (like glass) then most likely it is not acidic and will be okay for long term use. When it comes to food items there are numbers assigned to plastic containers. Some are more toxic than others. But the data from researchers and health & safety groups changes regularly so please see my note below about using plastic to hold food items and collectibles. But if you insist on using pages in a binder I recommend larger pockets, even if the bulky item is very small, because you want to be able to get your fingers (at least 2 fingers and your thumb) in and out of the pocket, possibly deep at the bottom of the pocket, to retrieve the part or jewelry item easily. This is unlike taking a card out of the pocket, when the card can easily be accessed at the very top. For couponing and other items that are not cards, I recommend 3 pocket pages. 100 Pro 3-Pocket Dollar Currency Collecting Storage Pages or 4 pocket pages. 20 (Twenty Pages) - BCW Pro 4-Pocket Page (3.5 X 5 Cards, Postcards or Photos) Four pocket pages are usually used to hold post cards and photos (do not use them for this reason unless they are non-pvc type). Three pocket pages are made for holding collectible paper money. Three pocket pages are usually not archival quality (because collectible paper money or "notes" are never place inside the 3 pocket page w/o first being housed in a archival sleeve) but that's okay because you really don't need archival acid free plastic for your coupons. Bottom line, you don't need non-pvc or expensive brand pages for your coupons. You just want pages that have good welds and won't tear. I've used both the 3 pocket and 4 pocket pages mentioned above and so far they are holding up fine. If I run into problems with them (if they tear) I'll be sure to update this review. ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ABOUT PLASTICS FOR HOUSING COLLECTIBLES (and food): When using any pages or plastic holders to house collectible items it is extremely important to get what is called "non-pvc" acid free pages/plastic, or "archival quality" pages/plastic. The reason for this is that any other kind of plastic (softer polyethylene) for example, will eventually excrete an oily gaseous acidic chemical that will ruin your cards (or anything else you put in the pages) and make them worthless. This leeching of acidic chemicals takes time, months or years, but once it happens irreversible damage is done to the item. The chemical found in pages that are NOT described as non-pvc is what allows the plastic to be pliable and soft. That's why non-pvc & archival quality plastics seem harder or crisper, less easily bendable; they don't have this acidic chemical that makes plastic pliable, or they have much less of it. This chemical is put in the plastic to help it bend and that chemical is what comes off the plastic over time (in a gas form) then attaches itself to the nearest thing - the item you placed in the pocket page. When the gas chemical attaches to the item it becomes sticky and slimy. This is extremely evident if the item you house is made of metal or hard plastic. After a while you can actually see a yellowish or green film on the item and you can feel the sticky slimy oily chemical. For paper or cardboard items you will notice a discoloration and possibly notice a slimy tacky feeling. Ether way the chemical is corrosive and as I said, ruins any thing it gets on. You can't really see it happening day to day because it's such a slow process. But it does happens and one day you'll go look at your collection and find it's discolored and ruined. Even if you try to clean the chemical damage off your item any professional will be able to see the damage with a loop, so you won't be able to clean the items and sell them to a dealer. So, NEVER buy any plastic to hold collectible items or items you will house long term unless the plastic is described as "non-pvc" or "archival" quality. If the sleeve, page or bag is described as "soft" but does not specifically say it's "archival quality" then most likely it is NOT archival quality. As a side note, this acidic corrosive chemical (pvc) is found to some degree in food grade plastic bags and pliable food containers. For this reason NO FOOD items should ever be held long term (more than a few weeks) in a soft plastic bag or pliable container and you should NEVER microwave your food in these containers. You also want to stay away from BPA containers when storing food and collectibles. BPA-free is best if you must use plastic for food storage. All food grade plastics are assigned a number; 1 thru 7. With some believing 3 and 7 to be the worst. For more info on these numbers and what they mean please do an internet search for EcoVillageGreen or plastic recycling numbers. No plastic is really 100% safe for food items but BPA-free is the best. Please be sure to educate yourself on using plastics before you use them with food items. To be safe, always use glass for long term food storage and microwaving. Yes, you would think the FDA would not allow this kind of plastic to be called "food grade" but that's a whole other issue for another day. ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ I hope this review helps you save money by allowing you to make an informed purchase. Happy collecting and couponing to you!!
summary: Perfect for what they are intended, not good for couponing, jewelry or crafts

The HL-2140 is a fine printer, and is often available for about $79 or less. It's easy to set up, and produces crisp, clean copies. The one drawback I've encountered so far is that the toner cartridge that comes with the printer  is sufficient for only about 300 pages of printing. This seems like a ripoff, as the only difference between this cartridge and the higher-yield  Brother cartridges is that they deliberately fill the starter cartridge only about 10%-20% full. Not a move calculated to enhance consumer loyalty!

Still, if you figure you can buy this printer PLUS four "high capacity" toner cartridges for around $300, you'll spend about 4-5 cents a page. (The "high capacity" TN-360 cartridge is nominally rated at 2,600  pages, but 1,500 is a more realistic estimate.)

My reasoning: (Vista Ultimate laptop)

1) It intelligently waits until the computer is idle, to auto-perform OCR chores. You have the option to do so as you scan, but this slows down scanning. There's also a menu click which yields a list of scans awaiting OCR-- really nice touch!

2) Unlike proprietary organizers, the "cabinets" created within the organizer software are actual directories on your hard disk. Likewise, folders created within the organizer's cabinets are subdirectories on your disk. So, you get the best of all worlds-- use the organizer knowing you're not locked in, as it's just a slick interface for what is actually existing on your drive. (i.e., Create a cabinet = create a directory)

3) Thermal receipts, even trying-to-fade ones, come thru crisp and clear, miraculously, when scanning.

4) I have Adobe Acrobat Professional 8, which is a necessary evil in my business. I can now avoid that bloated monster altogether when it comes to receipts and anything else I choose to scan using this system. That alone is worth the price of entry!

5) The duplex scanning is wondrous-- paper goes thru only once, with both sides captured simultaneously -- speedily. This still blows my mind (I have a duplex Canon MP830 multifunction-- for all practical purposes, its scanner has been blown away by this device.)

6) Let's face it-- sometimes, paper jams. This is the FIRST machine encountered-- since the late 80's when I started computing--  which makes it so easy to fix things. You just push the little square silver arrow atop the scanner, open, get the paper, and close it. Incredibly easy and no-fuss! And yes, the wrinkled paper then flows thru fine (I gently kept a finger on that one item as it scanned thru, just to be safe.) BTW, I had scanned upwards of 300 items before a jam occurred.

7) Lots of options, re speed, resolution, etc. All easy to get to, all quick to implement. These folks actually used this thing during the creation process, as it seems they didn't miss a trick in making this a genuinely consumer friendly device!

8) The consumables are comparatively cheap. The pad assembly (Part # PA03541-0002) needs replacement every 10,000 sheets or a year-- google the actual part # to see the $8 retailers); the pick roller (Part # PA03541-0001) lasts about 100,000 sheets-- about $12. I noticed a huge price variation among retailers while googling, so I placed my order today; they're not in stock at most places, but I have plenty of time so who cares. This is bound to be a profoundly popular scanner per word-of-mouth, and consumable prices may increase accordingly. BTW, right-click the ScanSnap Manager tray icon for "check consumable supplies" to get a tally on current sheet usage, which you can reset during the replacement process.

9) Small footprint-- lives in a bookcase shelf atop my desk.

10) One of the rare occasions where I've had absolutely no post-purchase regrets with an electronic item!

Long and short of it is this: I've finally lived long enough to see one hardware manufacturer get everything right. There's a pdf manual, but I read it only to investigate consumables (thought it would be a "gotcha!" but was pleasantly suprised at the reasonable cost). I assume you're reading these reviews carefully (as I did), trying to decide between the ScanSnap and a lower priced alternative. For once, I decided not to play cheapskate, and boy oh boy, am I glad!! (The price here has already escalated a bit, so do it now, my friend!)
Good quality and good price.

The Canon MX532 is an al-in-one inkjet color printer.  If you need a printer at home, it is just practical to get one that can do everything.  The MX532 can print, scan, copy and send fax.

The most important to me is to print from my mobile devices.  I store most of my documents in the cloud and the ability to print from my iPad, phone and laptop is now a necessity. The MX532 can also print directly from Flickr, Facebook, etc. if that matters anything to you.  This is also the quietest printer I ever had.

ADF:
The automatic feeder is a big plus compared to older printers.  It can accommodate 30 pages so that you don't have to lift the cover if you need to scan, copy multiple sheets.

Wifi:
Where is the uppercase and numeric characters?

I never done the WPS way and always configure it the standard way.  It defaults to WPS configuration first so I had to canceI to make the printer look for an access point. Once I found my SSID, I started typing my password.  The manual didn't say clear how to input uppercase and number.  I keep pressing the key hoping it will cycle from lowercase to uppercase and then numbers.  It didn't work that way. You have to press the asterisk once to switch it to uppercase and then press asterisk again to do the numbers.

Initially, my problem with the older MX522 is that sometimes I lose connection to the printer. I found out that when this happens I was not using the right SSID.  I have a guess WiFI network and sometimes my iPad or iPhone automatically connects to the Guess instead of the main WiFi network. The simple solution is to connect to the right SSID.  Rarely, but it happens too that I am on the right SSID but my device cannot find the printer.  Turning off and turning on the printer solves the problem.

Airprint:
My Macbook Air and IOS devices immediately found the printer.  Now I have a selection of 520 or 530 series.  Printing emails and pics is a cinch.

Copier:

I do not know why there are so many negative reviews on these highlighters.  Once you get used to how they write they are amazing. You just have to get used to the end of them because it changes the more you use one side (like a crayon). BUT because of this you can have a skinny, medium, or thick line all depending on what you want. It's great.

They glide across your paper, they never ever bleed through, they are really vibrant colors, and can see the lightest of pencil through them very clearly. They can't dry up, even if you loose the cap off. Unlike regular highlighters, they can't run out of ink. If you accidently loose the cap, just roll up the pen and it will never get color on anything.

I've had the same pink, orange, and yellow set since they first came out and the colors are as bright as when I first bought them, despite the fact that I lost the cap to two of them a long time ago. The color never fades or smears either. Papers that I highlighted two years ago are just as bright today! I can highlight right over freshly written gel ink and it still won't smear.

I just bought the new blue and green colors and they are just as amazing just like the original colors. I never will go back to the old fashioned highlighters.
These are soo much better than the pilot v7's i used to use. the Pilots would always bend eventually and these are much stronger and feel smoother. I love Uni-Ball PENS!
summary: SOOOO MUCH BETTER THAN THE PILOTS!

reviewText: It's a toner cartridge. It works. End of story

I seldom write bad reviews, since most products work well and are as advertised.  But this item is a waste of money for some.  In short, it works very well on round pencils, but abysmally on pencils that have six sides, such as the Palomino Blackwings or the Papermate Mirado classics.

On the former, a fine smooth point is easily acquired, on the latter, the point is lead comes out jagged, as if it has been hacked rather than sharpened.  Truly unusable for some pencils.

Strange that it should be so, since the wood on all pencils is sharpened to a cylinder, but I'm writing it as I experience it, and will now order new sharpness for my "good" Palomino pencils.

(By the way, there is a special Palomino Blackwing sharpener, but that too had its problems.  It leaves a ledge.  So now I'm stumped about how to find a good sharpener.  Any ideas?)
summary: Works well only on CERTAIN TYPES of pencils, NOT ALL!

reviewText:
The package contains 5 sets of tabbed plastic 3-hole punched divider sheets.  Each set of tabbed sheets has an untabbed front sheet, 8 graduated tabbed sheets (so you can read all 8 easily at the same time) and another untabbed sheet.  These sets are held together by a plastic locking strip.  The tabbed sheets are colored going left to right they are clear, light green, blue, yellow, orange, light blue, a greenish yellow, and a dark blue.  The locking strip is fairly easy to remove.

These are made to fit into 3 ring binders but could also be used in pocket folders to keep order in a folder between categories rather than doing multiple folders for one company or issue.  This is my use for these so that I can organize projects and company correspondence, contracts, project notes, invoices, billing, etc in a pocket folder.

I can certainly see the utility in using them in a 3-hole punch folder but just don't have the space handy to my work area to store them within reach and I do have a filing cabinet in easy reach.

I have had this Casio KL-60L label printer and I am very dissatisfied with it.  Every aspect of its use is wasteful.  It puts out too much tape at the end of my text when printing--waste tape.

Batteries have to be replaced frequently--how much electricity can it possibly take to run this tiny motor & print head???  Wasteful.

What caps it off is that near the end of a cartridge it stops printing.  I could still see more ribbon.  Took apart the cartridge and found nearly a yard of unused ribbon at the end.

Do you think this inspires me to buy any replacement parts for this product?  Resounding NO!

Do you think it inspires me to buy anything else casio produces?  Resounding NO!

What you have here is a "cheap" labeler that is going to cost you much more in wasted supplies.

Also, backing tape is very difficult to remove from label.  Dymo figured out how to handle this with those old thick plastic embossed labels; why can't casio get a clue?

It does make decent labels.

reviewText:
I was disappointed in these gel pens. Some of the cons I found were:
* inconsistent ink flow
* silver barrel below nib needed tightening on most pens
* the touted plastic holding case is very lightweight/flimsy
* ink ran out quickly
* very apt to smudge unless given at least 30 seconds to dry before touching
* some colors ran so "wet" that they bled through lighter weight paper
* other colors were more "dry" and scratchy/jerky

There were some pros:
* all the pens worked
* there is a good color selection
* there's a nice choice between metallic, neons and regular colors
* the nibs are fine enough to be able to color in small spaces (make sure you leave plenty of time for each color to dry!)

I'm loving most things about the malden. The leather is good, soft and authentic. It has fantastic functionality and looks great. It's also the perfect size to put in my purse and it helps keep me organized. The included inserts were a nice touch. For those curious, you get:

- A three year calendar on one page and pages that list holidays and special days all around the world.
- An entire calendar year in the form of a week on two pages. Mine started in July 2015 and ended on January 2017.
- A ruler/page divider.
- A top loading plastic sleeve.
- A lined notepad that hooks into the back pocket.
- 6 page dividers.
- A small assortment of colored, lined, graph and blank papers. Around 20-30 sheets total in the assortment.

I actually ended up removing the inserts that came with the planner because I preferred to use my own. But it's very thoughtful of them to include these so someone can just get this planner and start using it right away.

My biggest complaint about this planner might seem like a pretty minor issue to some, but it is a major pain in the butt for me. The pen loop is a great idea. I love that I can hook in a pen and keep it with my planner. Super convenient. Unfortunately, the included loop is way, way, way too small. Yes, you can stretch it out, but it's ridiculous the amount of effort this takes for certain pens. A great deal of the planner community uses multipens and those are really thick. No way will you be able to fit a five-color multipen into this pen loop right out of the box. I use fountain pens primarily, and many of mine are thicker than the average ballpoint or gel pen too. I've been training my planner's loop for the better part of a month, and this loop still isn't big enough to accommodate the pen that I actually want to use. They can cut out this nonsense by just providing a larger pen loop right out of the factory.
summary: Fantastic planner, only flaw is the pen loop.

reviewText:
What can I say?  This is the sharpener I have been waiting for all my life.  Think of all those bad pencil sharpening experiences you've had, since grade school, and all the different kinds of sharpeners, even those old big bulky electric ones.  I got some vintage one that was supposed to be a favorite among architects, for $50.00.  I was even going to buy that book called, How to sharpen a pencil, but I'm glad I held off.  I've been led down the isle more than once by reviewers in love with their pencil sharpeners.  I thought the Blackwing was going to be it.
You already know the specs.  All I know is that it has 3 holes, and you can make the point long or short, and I've not had one problem. Plus, what's the deal with this, it's like "conservative," in use of the pencil.  I've noticed there is not as much waste, and it takes less time to sharpen it.  It's a solid little sharpener, metal.  Compact enough, not tiny; you can stick it in your pocket or purse.  I
The points work.  The "lead," doesn't fall out.  It does not chew up the pencil.  You don't have to empty it.  I grind it over the garbage can next to my work table.
I am an artist/painter, and Iconographer.  I use a pencil quite a bit, daily, sometimes for hours.  With mixed media, I am often using all kinds of pencils, from graphite, to charcoal, to pastel, you name it.  Esp. for the money, do yourself a favor and try this one.
I am going to buy these as gifts for people for Christmas this year.  Super cool looking in person, too.
Also, not one paid me to write this. I did not recieve any discount. Not that it's bad, just saying.
summary: Perfect in every way; thank you for finally making a sharpener that performs.

The Swingline LightTouch Punch's lever is much easier to use than the HeavyDuty Punch's handle. (Swingline LightTouch Heavy Duty Paper Punch (A7074357B) often requires using two hands: one for the lever and the other to hold the punch in place.) But there were no instructions save for the cryptic information on the back of the box. The locking mechanism for the lever is unnecessarily difficult to figure out right away. The plastic thing with the arrows on it slides to lock/unlock as the handle is held down. This makes for a "duh" moment once it's figured out, but better instructions would make this simpler. This lock seems to be only to make storage easier by lowering the profile on the lever. The lever needs to be in the unlocked position to punch holes. The tray that holds the punched paper is also awkward. The idea is that the tray slides away from the main body, but it opens only about an inch. Tipping the punch into a waste basket still makes the punched holes go where they should not, and it's difficult to get every last one out. Prior to sliding the tray, make sure you bang and tilt the punch in the direction of the arrows to improve your chances of getting those paper bits as close to that one inch opening as possible. THEN slide the tray open. DON"T try to remove the plastic tray from the punch itself. It's so easy to do accidentally, but very hard to put back.
summary: Punching Holes is Easy (But Instructions are Cryptic)

I have used Epson products for decades, and they just keep getting better.

They are a joy in part because they are easy to get out of the box, unpack, and install. Before this one, I made the mistake of giving HP a chance. That printer was a nightmare in terms of setting it up. The only glitch I had with the Epson this time was that for some reason I was unable (at least at this point) to register the product. However, I got it working wirelessly without any trouble and set up everything else with ease.

The printer immediately began printing both documents and photographs without any glitches. I am very happy with the documents. Though the color photos are not, of course, as vivid as color laser output (the best color laser I ever had was an Okidata, but the replacement toner was outrageous), they are quite good.

One of the cool features of this product is the inability to directly email the printer. It also has the ability to print on both sides and is energy efficient. I also really liked that the cassette holds 500 pages.

Another thing to consider about Epson is that you get lifetime phone support if you have any issues, which you probably won't. You will not find a better printer at this price point.

This is a small, fairly portable document scanner.  Good for a small setup or anyone who wants to avoid clutter.  Two things to know:
1. It doesnt come with a power adapter, instead you power it via a USB cable.  If you don't have a newer USB 3.0 port you will need two USB cables: one for data and the other for power.  You can alternately purchase a power adapter.  For some this is a pain, but I love that I can connect and power this thing with one USB3.0 cable.
2. While it will scan without loading the drivers off the disk it will work better if you install the Canon drivers.  Canon has a lite version of their CaptureOnTouch software that can run directly off the scanner, however to enable all of the features you need to install the full drivers off the disk or download them from Canon (go to the product page on Canon and click on the Drivers and Software link.

Functionally it works well and will get the job done for a small office or home use.  If you are scanning documents all day you probably want something with faster throughput, but if you are just looking for a portable document/card scanner with a small footprint this is a pretty good option.
summary: Great for a home or small office

Quartet makes good whiteboards, which is why they are so ubiquitous.  They are sturdy, and this magnetic one is particularly tough and resistant to warping.  The ability to use magnets is great and often useful.  I like to leave notes and outlines that will stay for long periods, since ink left of over long periods can stain.  With that said, the board cleans easily so far.  The surface is bright and slick.  One marker and a couple magnets were included.

I think the real test of a whiteboard is how it ages.  Will it begin to bow out of shape, requiring the corners to be screwed into the wall to hold it flat?  Will the surface stain?  I will let you know if any of these happen.  Until then, I don't have any complaints.  It is a great whiteboard.

When I took this locker shelf out of the box I was immediately impressed by how sturdy and solid it is. I really do think it can hold the 100lbs it claims to and then some. We stand a bunch of books on it before sending it to off to school with our daughter and it held the books with no bending or movement. The one problem we had was with the drawer. The drawer is ok as a place to stash occasional use items but it doesn't slide very well so it's not really a replacement for a pencil cup.

This isn't the lockermate you remember from middle and high school. It doesn't fold down, disassemble, or adjust in anyway. It is what it is. This can be both a pro and a con. When your child gets their locker you'll have to drive them. No way could a kid walking or riding a bike reasonably carry this and taking it on the bus would be a challenge.

Bottom line, this is a great option for kids who are tough on their stuff and for parents who want a locker shelf that will never need replacing. We expect to be able to hand this down to our younger kids in a few years.

reviewText: We had an older analog Polycom that we replaced with the IP 5000 and have been very pleased with it. The room is about 12' x 12' and has quite a few hard surfaces, so calls tended to have echo for the people on the other end. I bought this phone in hopes that it would handle the calls and reduce echo better. It definitely has helped a lot! We may look into adding some sound absorption material, but this was the cheapest first option and was worth getting. Setting it up is easy enough of you have other VOIP devices. We input our provision server when booting up and it takes care of the rest. NOTE - this version is the POE one and does not contain an external power supply. This phone is not meant for large conference room. It doesn't have the microphone distance to support larger rooms. If you have larger conference room, consider the Polycom SoundStation IP 6000 without Power Supply (again this has no power supply, they offer a power supply version though) - I have a few of those purchased as well and really like them.
summary: Perfect for a smaller conference room

reviewText:
Normally when it comes to "photo" quality, inkjets have the edge, but with them come ink maintenance issues, printheads that clog or print white lines, and very expensive ink ($1/ml).  Inkjets are a bit of a hassle but the quality can be spectacular.

When I did the demo in the office supply store on the 1518ni I was just blown away buy the photographic quality print on normal office paper.  I had never seen such quality on a laser which usually has scan lines from the rotating laser head.  I read up a bit about HP's new "color sphere" toner which is the trick to making the whole system work.  The tonerparticles are much smaller than previous color toners allowing the print engine to mix 1, 2, or 3 of one color along with numerous specs of toner from the other cartridges  before heading to the fuser.  This gave the quality which was more than adequate for proofing, and could even be used on high grade paper for prints.  HP kept is simple on this product as well - there is a pull out drawer with the 4 toner cartridges (don't forget to peal off the seal on the toner or else nothing prints at all - there is a green tab you snap then pull out twice the width of the cartridge in sealing tape which has become a much cleaner process than previous toner loading.

There is a down side - I paid $130 for the printer on sale which included the card readers, usb memory card reader, lcd display, and wired networking which I consider a good value. The fact that I can use it from any CPU in the buildings is a definite win. BUT-  When the time comes to replace the printer cartridges (4 remember) at 80 bucks a pop, its $320 to print roughly 2000 sheets.  As a result I kept my laserjet monochrome printer for documents and only use the 1518ni printer when I want a quick print to show someone or to make a quick color document for a customer.

And, as usual, HP gives you "starter" toner cartridges so your $320 investment will come sooner rather than later.  Beware of these $50 cartridges being sold as compatible also - they are much larger particle size and will not generate the spectacular color the genuine HP products will.  Sometimes HP has a sale on all 4 toners at once so you can watch hp.com for their pricing, and also sign up for their newsletter on ink and toner specials.

For the price I paid I was very impressed with the quality and simplicity of use.  I also have HP inkjet printers but every time I go to unclog the supplies I walk away with pink, yellow, blue, and of course black fingers.  This printer stays on my network in its energy star mode ready to print on a moments notice,  Speed is impressive as well.  If HP ditched the whole "starter cartridge" concept I'd be alot happier camper, but again the price was right.
summary: Simple to use, no clogged nozzles, photo quality laser color

I've used the basic G2 pens for years (their gel ink lets me write all day without getting hand cramps the way I do with regular ballpoints). On a bit of a lark, when I was purchasing some G2 refills, I decided to get a G2 Limited and a G2 Pro at the same time. How they compare (also, see the user photo I've attached to this listing): Regular G2 -- writes well and smoothly, under $2 each if you buy a dozen Pilot G2 Pro -- a bit thicker, heavier, more padding in the grip, under $3 G2 Limited (this pen) -- about the same thickness as the G2 Pro, considerably heavier, better finish / metal (vs. plastic) clip, much "squishier" grip (but not to the "Dr. Grip" level), about $11 Personally, I go back & forth between the Pro and Limited as to which is my "favorite." The G2 Limited is nicer looking (might be important in some offices), and has a nice heft, more expensive than the rest -- but still a bargain compared to the "usual suspects" of fancy pens. The G2 Pro is sufficiently professional looking for most offices, still has a good heft to it, and has a grip that's padded -- but not excessively (to my tastes). So I guess the choice comes down to how much weight, how much padding, and how much eye appeal you're looking for. As I mentioned, I've used G2 pens for years and never had one break on me -- I'm still using some on their 3rd and 4th refill. So, tough to go wrong with them! Get a Pro or a Limited (as a function of your taste), then buy it refills for years.
summary: Great pen, very luxurious look & feel for a reasonable price

As I get older the tremors in my hands have begun to get worse, and I bought this pen along with a set of penmanship books to re-learn how to write well. I had a much more expensive fountain pen already, and this one was specifically for keeping at my desk at home.

But then I got to using it and, while I was unimpressed with the appearance (simple, matte black) it was the kind of understated product I do prefer. It wouldn't qualify as "elegant", but it is more attractive than I expected.

As to the use of the pen; the more I use it, the more pleased I am. It came with both a plate press cartridge (refillable via ink bottle; the thing people who don't use fountain pens picture) and a replaceable ink cartridge. Being that it's still primarily for practice I use the cartridges for the sake of simplicity, and have not had the opportunity to test the plate press. When I do, I'll update this review.

The lines have been smooth and easy, the nib is sturdy and doesn't catch, and the weight of the pen is on the heavy side, but easy to use for hours at a time.

Regarding the ink, I ordered a pack of Pilot/Namiki IC-100 cartridges, and it took me several dozen pages to exhaust the first of them. The ink does not dry in or on the nib in such a way as to cause any difficulty, and I've only had to clean the tip of dried ink once, when I left the pen sitting for several days without use. Of course those who use fountain pens will know this is a no-no, but if this is your first such pen then try to make sure you get the ink flowing (write!) every couple of days at the least. That said, clean-up was simple and took less than 5 minutes. Pilot includes clean-up instructions in the box.

I'm not an expert calligrapher or fountain pen enthusiast. I bought this product because, simply, it was recommended by Amazon with the penmanship guide I was purchasing the same day, and I have been increasingly pleased with that decision every day since.

The Day-Timer Organizer Refill is an auto-buy for me every Fall.  I simply cannot gannet get along without this time management product!  I've used this system for three decades, and I find it indispensable. Prior to finding Day-Timer, I used a more costly equivalent brand which had been a pioneer of time management systems in the 80s. The Day-Timer product itself deserves five stars; the sole reason that I've given it four stars is the somewhat confusing price fluctuations to which this product is subject. In late 2013, I noticed a price drop shortly after I'd ordered my 2014 refill, and I chalked it up to unfortunate timing on my part. This year, I ordered the 2015 refill and, on the day I received the product, I again noticed a price decrease of over $3, a significant percentage of this item's purchase price. Fortunately, Amazon agreed to remedy this situation with a refund, but I am not pleased at having to perform this extent of due diligence caused by the (seasonal?) price volatility of this one product. If the price can stabilize (eliminate seasonal variations), then this product would certainly warrant five stars.

I used the top three tiers as magazine holders & the bottom tier as a brochure holder.
First Tier - Holds 9 65 page magazines (fairly thick paper).
Second Tier - Holds 12 51 page magazines.
Third Tier - Holds 11 56 page magazines.
Forth Tier - Holds 10 area maps (fairly bulky) & 30 tri-fold brochures.

The holder itself is made of very durable acrylic, which is great, it should hold up very well to normal wear and tear. It's a nice thick acrylic, so I'm not concerned about it being knocked off the counter and broken, I think at most it might spider crack if it falls from a great distance, but most acrylics are like that.

Best deal on the market!

PROS
1. One of the more reasonable film digitizers. (Still pretty pricey considering its construction and glitches.)
2. Images from negatives look great to me. It has settings for b/w and color and outputs very high res.  (Haven't tried slides yet.)
3. Portable. You don't have to hook it up to a computer to use it so you can sit anywhere next to an outlet and scan. (Needs an extension cord as the provided one is short.)
4. Settings to adjust, flip and turn the negatives though if your doing many its faster to just adjust them in photo editing software later.
5. Quick scanning. Couple of seconds for each negative in the strip.

NEITHER PRO NOR CON
1. Digitizes  "typical" 35mm film and 110 only. Larger negatives, which I have quite a few, will not work.
2. Holds a strip of 6 35mm negatives.

CONS
1. Trays are hard to open and tricky to line up the little nibs to the film if you have less than a full strip of six negatives.
2. Some 35mm film, possibly from instant cameras, don't line up with the dividers on the tray. So those have to be move adjusted for each single frame. (I uploaded a photo.)
3. Extra trays are very pricy though nice to have a couple to speed up scanning a lot of negatives.
4. Does NOT do 126 negatives. I have no idea why they don't make a tray for those. My husband made me one with cardboard that works great to use for this format with this scanner.
5. Other machine auto adjust the color and contrast after you put a negative or slide in. I've had quite a few color negatives not auto adjust right and come in VERY light though the negative is fine. Not sure why this is. I can usually adjust them in my editing software after I scan but that is the one glitch that bothers me at least on the one I purchased.

THOUGHTS
Taking into consideration there not many choices for standalone inexpensive film scanners that have decent ratings, this one works fine overall for what I wanted which was a portable digitizer with a card and preview screen. I've scanned a few hundred negatives already and find it adequate for my needs.

Having an inexpensive light board is incredibly useful when working with negatives in general and makes loading these tray much easier when it's done on top of the board as shown in my photos I uploaded.

NOTE: To see my images you have to click below the main item graphic where it says "See all Customer Images" They do not show default. :-(

FOLLOWUP June 28 2013
I have now scanned thousands of negatives... black and white and color 35 mm and a few slides. Also 110 negatives.  I love this thing even with its minor glitches. As I have literally thousands of negatives and slides to scan in I do many of them laying propped up on my bed scanning while I watch TV. The portable factor of this scanner is off the charts wonderful for me.  I recommend this to anyone wanting a overall inexpensive scanner that does the job for home negatives. I've blogged about this on my family web site for anyone wanting more photos. therectorfamily (dot) com
summary: All things considered a decent digitizer.

What's not to love about ths printer?  I have a few Canon portables, a very small Selpy just for photos and two BJ's. I used to use my BJ 85 with my laptop. However, now that I have a new laptop in Windows 7, it will no longer work.

The Pixma works flawlessly in Windows 7 and is a far more sophisticated, slicker machine than the BJ 85 and far more solidly built. Another feature which makes it far superior is the built in seal in the machine which keeps the ink from drying out. In the old BJ's that was a constant problem and I had all kinds of special Canon cannisters to prevent the ink from drying up, which never worked very well.

I had an issue when I first set it up. The instructions say to remove the "film" from the print head.  Well, it turns out the translation of "film" is a bit weird. By film, they mean the orange, hard plastic container type thing that you have to snap the print head out of. To me that is hardly "FILM".  So I struggled to remove the shiny brown thin film like stuff on the bottom of the print head, only to learn that that was not what they meant and wound up destroying the print head!

I called Canon and they were truly great.  They sent me a brand new replacement print head 2nd day FedEx.

Now all is good to go and the machine is terrific.

Definetly a winner!

reviewText:
This is one of Epson's new line of printers incorporating PrecisionCore technology, something that's supposed to give higher resolution for text and faster output speed. The 7620, 7610, and 7110 are wide-format printers, handling up to 13x19 paper, with two-sided printing or faxing up to 11x17 paper. The 7610 holds 250 sheets while the 7620 holds 500 sheets of paper. The 7110 model is like the 7620, eliminating the all-in-one aspects, and printing but without fax or scan capacity.

Unpacking and setup both went smoothly as I connected the printer to my wifi network, entering my password on the printer's keypad. I was then quickly able to access the printer's IP address from my Mac laptop and upgraded the firmware to the latest version - not a necessity, but figured for the review I should use Epson's latest. There was no need to use the included CD-ROM as my desktop and laptop Macs (running OS 10.9.4) both saw the printer and could utilize it without difficulty.

I compared this printer to the new Epson WF-3640, which is roughly the same unit but with only letter sized paper. What I said in my review for that unit applies here as well: The printer copies, scans, faxes, prints, connects directly to SD or MS Duo cards, prints two-sided (significantly faster than older units, where there was a time delay while print on one side dried), prints from your iPhone, and probably more. Everything works, and works quickly without a lot of wasted time. I still find the output of a monochrome laserwriter to be just a little cleaner than inkjet output, but this inkjet is about on a par with a color laser unit, the output from which often appears just a little blurry compared to a monochrome unit's. This is meant as a workplace unit - the ink combination isn't the best for photographs, so if that's a key plan of yours, look to another printer (Epson and Canon both have good offerings here). But for a work plan cover sheet, or a bio that includes a head shot, this will do just fine. That's to say it's perfectly acceptable for photographs that aren't being viewed for their artistic quality.

I have no quibbles with this unit. Obviously, if you're not going to print 13x19" or 11x17" pages, and have no need for faxing or copying that size paper, there's no need to get this unit as it will be larger than your needs. But it's wonderful to occasionally be able to print poster-sized pages for posting at work or school.

There is a small setup worksheet that accompanies the printer. A 333 page full owner's manual is easily accessed online and will answer any specific questions you have about the product or its use.

This is the second one we bought. High School Jr. uses these for every day classes. She prefers the paper to not be torn out or messing with peeling away the "feathers" of the notebook style perforated books. reviewText:
O.K.! I admit that I send out much more mail than most folks I know! AND, I admit I LOVE to use stamps that
"Say Something" about what I like ... so I order many different ones.
MANY of the ones that I like ONLY are available as "Full Sheets" and NOT as "COILS".
I am so "crazy" about my stamps selection ... AND the love of convenience ....
That I actually MAKE the "Full Sheets" into "COILS" and then place them into keepers.

MOST of the keepers that I have bought over the years are fine and work as expected.
SOME of them are now "Collectible"!
But THIS KEEPER is my FAVORITE!
Since most of it is transparent ... I can SEE the stamps inside so I can select the one I want to use
for the particular piece of mail I am sending out.
I can ALSO see how many stamps are left in the keeper (THAT is handy).
I now have a dozen of THESE KEEPERS alone (and only TWO are still empty). This one really works for ME!
If you have a need for a stamp keeper - I strongly suggest THIS ONE!
{Did my review help you decide?}.
summary: GREAT way to keep stamps HANDY!

ACCURACY. I have had this scale for about three months, and almost always, it weighs within .1 or .2 ounces of what it weighs when I take it to the post office.

Here's what they don't tell you (amazing how bad some companies explain their own products) ... if you need to carry two "credit card" thickness cards, like badges, insert the cards and see if the second card fits too tight (it will get tighter the further down you push it).  If one or both of your cards has an id chip (gold) on it, you don't want it to be too tight, especially if you must remove it for scanning at times. There are two thin plastic elements separating the two cards, pull one out with a set of needle-nose pliers (once the 'nubs' at the bottom give way, it'll come right out), re-insert the 2nd card (badge), it may now be too loose. When you get this badge holder, it comes with a 'Specialist' logo card, same size as your badge, but thin like a single card from a deck of cards.  Insert it, add your 2nd badge and see if it is snug enough.  If it isn't quite snug enough, fold the bottom third of card up to make the bottom a bit thicker, and try again. To test, turn holder upside down and shake it downward to see if the cards come out ... for me, they stayed in place when shakin' upside down with moderate force, but still easy to insert and remove as needed.  Add a 3rd external card to the plastic loop connecting the holder to a lanyard, it's compact, visible, and easy to flip over if you present two forms of ID.
summary: Here's what they don't tell you (amazing how bad some companies explain their own products)

reviewText: I have used this toner consistently over the years but am amazed at the ever increasing cost for a mediocre capacity for prints.

Pros:  The phone rings.  I can receive and make calls.

Cons:  The volume doesn't go as high as I'd like.  When using the speaker function, the sound comes out from the back and is very tinny, and once turned on, the speaker function can't be turned off until the call is ended.  If you like using the speaker function, that's no problem, but I use it only when I'm making a business call and am put on hold, "waiting for the next agent."  Once the "agent" comes on line, I turn off the speaker function, but am unable to do so with this phone.  The answering machine function has no window indicating how many calls are on the machine.  A light does blink when a new message has been left, but there's no indication of how many incoming new messages there are or how many old messages there are.

This cost a lot of money but I'm replacing it.
summary: Too Many Things Wrong With It

reviewText:
Update (3/28/16):
This printer worked great for the few months that it stayed connected to my network. One day a few months ago it simply failed to connect, and a new computer and network later I STILL can't get it to print. It's ridiculous that something as simple as connecting to a wireless network would make an otherwise good product no more useful that a paper weight.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
I Love this printer, but it looses a star for the difficult setup. I am a fairly tech savvy individual and it still took me 2 hours to set this up with reading through the reviews. The quick setup instructions are essentially useless. A couple of tips before I comment on the actual printer. Taking the previous reviewer's advice you will definitely have to upgrade the firmware on this. You must first set up the printer with the manual wireless setup. After that you will be able to print wirelessly. If you then want to do the wireless direct to print from your phone you must then upgrade the firmware, THEN go back to the first set up disk and do a direct wireless setup. Having to basically set up the printer TWICE is where I got stuck in the process. From then on, it works flawlessly.

The printer itself is great! I got it at a steal from a big box store, which made it even more worthwhile. It is compact, and the design allows me to store it under my (elevated) bed rather than use precious surface space in my small apt. The auto duplexing is a dream and the print quality is spectacular. I have printed images on the brother laser printer and this and this definitely wins. Even fine graphics (pwpt notes slides) print with clarity. I have also been able to print from my phone with ease, however, I have a Samsung phone so I can't speak to the compatibility of other systems.

Another point, which was something that I ran into when doing my research on different models was what exactly is the difference between the
SL-M2830DW  and the SL-M2835DW models. The only difference between the two is this model (2830) combines the drum and toner) the 2835 has a 2 piece unit (toner and imaging unit) which is supposed to reduce the cost per page. However, the toner cost is about the same regardless of the printer model. With the imaging unit, having  a life of 9k pages you're gonna be coughing up an extra $40 for every 4th toner replacement. Ultimately, I don't think I'll print enough to break even with the 2 piece unit so I went with this model. Also at the time of purchase this model was about half the cost of the 2835.
summary: Setup is frustrating, but ultimately worth it.

reviewText:
This scanner is fabulous. Works like a charm. Gobbles up the pages at about 1 per second and scans both sides and no matter how many pages you load, a few seconds after it scans the last page, a thumbnail view shows up on your screen of all pages. You can have it then do character recognition or not. I have scanned a couple of thousand pages by now and I had 4 misfeeds. Three were because I overlooked stapled pages. The sound sensor detects the crumbling of paper during a misfeed and quickly turns off the feed motor so your page is not shredded. Very small footprint, very intelligent design. The scanner manual is probably in the top 2% of well written manuals that I have ever seen. Clear, logical, photos, arrows detail, hyperlinked.

My only gripe is that there is no documentation for the software and although it is easy to load and works flawlessly, it took quite some time to figure out exactly how to use it. You have to first create "Driver Profiles" that contain the options that you want. Then you create scanner profiles and select other options that you want and select a driver profile to go along with it. The combinations are endless. Color only. B&W only. Auto color recognize. Various resolutions. OCR or not? Pdf or jpeg? Their PaperStream software is brand new and there is already a newer version on their website to download. There are options in the software for things I have never heard of, and evidently would only be useful in an enterprise environment.

I contacted Fujitsu twice and got English speaking people answering the phone who were knowledgeable and polite. I must be dreaming. I highly recommend this product. Very satisfied, but ouch it is costly.

1/21/2014 Update: Just finished scanning 5000 pages since I bought it. I believe there were only 2 misfeeds that were my fault (forgetting to remove a staple). It has now told me that it is now scheduled for its 5000 page cleaning so I called Fujitsu to ask a question about that, a very nice ENGLISH speaking person answered and told me that I really do not need to pay for the cleaner and pads specified in the manual, just use isopropyl alcohol greater than 90%. I did, worked fine, saved money. ANOTHER positive interaction w Fujitsu. Then I went into the software to reset the counter for cleaning to "0" so that it will let me know in another 5000 pages. There are other page counters that will let you know when it may be time for replacement of different feed rollers, and then there is a global page counter that cannot be reset. I am very impressed.

What is interesting is that I originally performed my research and settled on the HP Scanjet Flo 7000 which is also a new model and has very similar features. I ordered it directly from HP and the shipping date kept getting pushed back, and back. I kept calling and emailing Hp to ask for a realistic shipping date. They kept giving me different excuses such as, "I tried contacting the warehouse and I can't get through", then "I sent an email to the warehouse to ask and they have not responded", then it was "there was a large rain storm that knocked out the electricity and the servers are down and it won't be until tomorrow when they come up." Delays, lies at Hp caused me to cancel the order and go with the Fujitsu Fi-7160. I could not be happier with how things worked out. Interestingly, in the last month I noticed Fujitsu scanners at hospitals and other large corporations that I have been in, not HP.

5/18/2017 Update
Still amazed how wonderful the scanner is. Flawless. Never jams, unless I forgot to remove a staple. I decided to upgrade to the newest version of Paperstream software since I was still using version 1.0 from 3 years ago. Easily went to the Fujitsu website, easy download, easy install. Unfortunately, all the scan profiles I had created with Version 1.0 were not carried over, so I had to recreate them... I half expected that to happen. Glad to see that the usability of the software is greatly improved from the 1st version. The right click Adhoc feature lets you change any part of a profile for just one scan, very cool. So a couple days after I created my 8 scan profiles, I opened up the program and they were all GONE! Not happy. I remembered my great experience the last time I called customer support, so I decided to try that again, although I was truly expecting that they went the way of everyone else and now contract their customer service out to a company in Siberia. Amazing, went through one phone menu, was on hold for 20 seconds, and my call was answered by a real, live, native English speaking ADULT. And he was fully competent and was able to solve my issue immediately. Another great experience. Thank you Fujitsu.

3/5/2018 Update
This baby is still cranking. FLAWLESS. I hope Fujitsu will consider making cars. :-)

I've had mine for a couple years and it's been the most pleasurable printer experience for me. For many years I had an Apple LaserWriter Plus 630 and an Epson or HP color ink jet printer. Most of what I print can be in B&W and the LaserWriter would do a great job and quick too. Ink jets can give great color prints but they are so slow and the ink is always running out since it uses so much of it to prime itself or clean the print head. I've grown to hate them. If you print a high volume of color prints then you'll get many more pages out of the ink but for someone who only prints a small volume of pages more of the ink is used up priming when the printer is turned on and used for unclogging the print head.

So my reliable and very long time LaserWriter finally developed bad issues in the electronics and wouldn't work sometimes. So I had to find a printer solution that best met my needs which was B&W and low volume color printing, and reliable and low maintenance. This HL4040CN is what I bought for that and it's been awesome. Sure it doesn't print photo grade color but the positive trade off is that I get very fast and reliable color printing and the color looks beautiful. Some complain about the colors not being so true and I assume they are Windows users printing with the default color setting whereas Macs have a built-in color matching system ColorSync which calibrates the colors and makes a very nice improvement on the color tone.

The size is BIG. I'm used to that since I've used full sized office network laser printers which I've found to be rugged and reliable as opposed to the small home grade laser printers which can be temperamental and break more easily. This HL4040CN looks very ruggedly built like my past 3 LaserWriters all of which lasted a very long time and I hope that this one will to.

Envelope feeding is the one minor annoying thing with this printer. You have to pop the back cover open and adjust 2 levers for the thicker stock and then it works perfectly. Instructions are in the manual for how to set this.
summary: Reliablle Color and Calibrates to Mac ColorSync

I got off my Parker kick for a moment just to try something new and different.

I purchased a Pilot Prera Clear Body (elsewhere) for 4 times the money, and just plain like this Nemosine 4 times better. That makes the Nemosine a winner 16 to 1.

This demo filled easily, fits my hand well and has nice balance, and the ink (Noodler's) began to flow right away and has remained smooth and consistent. Fill method is piston, and works well (wish all converters would hold more, there seems to be barrel space for it). I chose the Fine Point nib, but it seems closer to a medium, as do a lot of Parker Fine nibs.

For the price, the only thing that comes close is the free Noodler's demo pens that you can sometimes find with their larger bottles.
My plan is to buy several more Nemosines, and use this demo with a clear barrel for various colored inks. The cap threads on, opposed to friction fit, and is very nice for keeping ink fresh and ready to flow when you're ready.

Noodler's inks work great in all my fountains, wide color selection, and downright fun.

fwiw: When I bought the Pilot Prera, I also purchase the Pilot Penmanship Fountain Pen. This is for penmanship training, with a 3-sided grip to help learn proper pen holding. At $8, this is a nice pen for that purpose, nice weight and balance, converter or cartridge fill, and smoother than the Prera. It too would be great if you want a special pen for each of your special inks, but my personal choice for this remains the Nemosine.
summary: Nemosine Singularity -- Smooth and consistent, easy to handle -- and a fantastic bargin for a daily or specialty fountain

reviewText:
I have to have a good stapler for my office. I spend half of my day stapling papers. I was using a Paper Pro Evo stapler but, it wasn't working that well. I came across the PraxxisPro brand and decided to give it a try. I am so glad that I did.

  The Basileus Grip Stapler is wonderfully designed. Because I use a stapler so much, the design means a lot. This stapler is comfortable to grip and hold for long periods. It has just the right amount of weight to it. The color is exceptional. The deep maroon makes locating the stapler easy.

  Usually, spring loaded staplers are annoying. However, that isn't the case with this one. I love the easy to load design. I can also use any standard size staples in it. When you order the Basileus stapler, it comes with a decent size pack of staples.

  I love that I can staple large stacks of paper. It is rated to staple 25 sheets at a time and, it does with ease. This stapler even has a nice staple puller on the end. The 2 in 1 features saves me a lot of time.

  Overall, this is a great deal. I received this item in exchange for my honest review. I would purchase office supplies from this company any day.
summary: Heavy duty stapler with attached staple puller.
