reviewText: I write for a living, and I have a thing about keyboard and pens. These are by far my favorite pens right now, and quite possibly my favorite pens ever. The last time I went to Japan, I picked up two of these (along with some other gel pens) at Itoya, an incredible stationery store in Ginza. I'm kicking myself that I didn't pick up more. If you appreciate the feel of a pen on paper as you write, you have to try these. They don't simply glide across the paper as many gel pens do--you can feel the pen move on the paper, and at the same time, they're incredibly smooth (it's tough to describe, because I haven't used pens with just this feel before). The ink also seems to dry almost instantly.
summary: My favorite pens right now -- they don't feel quite like any other gel pen

reviewText: I love Sharpies and use them  A LOT! I love the variety of colors this collection provides! For some reason, the price fluctuates quite a bit for this item. So if you're patient and can wait, I'd wait until it's around $12 to buy it (which is how much I paid.)

We often have and use things regularly without thinking about them much, or if there's another brand out there besides what we've always used. Packaging tape is one of those things. We always bought 3m's Scotch tape, despite being continuously frustrated by it's performance. And I can tell you that yes, sometimes, the grass really is greener on the other side, and we'll be buying Zitriom LLC's packing tape from here on out!

To start, Zitriom's tape thicker than the Scotch brand tape, considerably so. And while that doesn't sound like much, not only does it make it stronger, but it also means it's not going to just flop over and stick to itself, or to something unintended as so often the case with the Scotch brand tape. It also stayed stuck. Which sounds like a "Well, duh!" statement, but until you've tried to secure boxes with tape that won't stay stuck on, don't "Duh!" me! The tape we've been using was always a crapshoot as to whether it'd stay stuck on things, and that will make you want to rip your hair out after a few failures. Zitriom's tape stayed put, period. The one thing that I didn't care for was the dispenser. Having used a "Tape Gun" now for a couple of decades, I found the dispenser flimsy, awkward and for me, dangerous. Maybe it was me, maybe I'm out of practice, but I tossed it almost immediately and stuck the Zitriom tape in my gun and never looked back. So look at the dispenser as a "Value Added" thing and not a make-or-break item in the set.

You get 6 rolls of premium packaging tape (each roll is 1.90" x 55 yards) for $10.98, which is almost 20% less than the closest version of the Scotch brand tape. It's not heavy duty, but it's plenty thick and I found it to be better than the 3M tape I was using, so I was happy with Zitriom's version of this and will buy it again when I need tape.

I received the above product(s) free of charge from Zitriom LLC. I am not obligated to provide a positive or favorable review, just my honest opinion. My review is based on my experience with the product and/or brand, which may differ from yours.
summary: Zitriom LLC's Six-Pack of Packing Tape and Dispenser

I bought 3 sets of ink, which contains a total of 6 Black cartridges.  I have a new WF 3540 Epson printer.  The color EZ ink cartridges, at least the 3 I put in work fine, but the Black cartridges cause an error on the printer.  I found that 2 of the black cartridges had NO ink in them, 2 only printed about 20 fax pages before running out of ink and the last 2 caused the printer to error out and I couldn't override the "Non-Epson" product override option, it would cause the print head to freak out and lock up the printer.
I also have a WF 3520 which I have been using a different re-manufactured ink and never had a problem.  They cost about 10 per cent more, but never had a bad one.
I will not purchase from this company again, their black cartridges are complete garbage - with 2 of the six shipping without ink, and 2 more with almost no ink in them and the last 2 not working in the printer at all.
I sent an email to their company with no response after a week, even though they state they respond within 24 hours.
summary: Black cartridges complete garbage with Epson WF 3540.

She decorates her room with them and my family enjoys choosing which ones to send to Nana that week.

Nice printer and inexpensive.  I mostly use it to print toner based images to transfer into beeswax images (called encaustic image transfer)  Much cheaper than running into Staples all the time to make toner based prints.  If I did it again I might choose the duplex model, and perhaps a model that handles a heavier paper with a straight through paper path, but I already have a printer that does that and I don't do enough printing to warrant it anyway.  Good printer.

And BTW.  Before I bought this I contacted Brother to see if anyone there had ever used its output for image transfers with beeswax.  They hadnt but mailed me some sample prints to try out.  Very appreciative of their kindness doing that.  My other printer is a Brother BTW and I like that as well.

reviewText: I like that this pen puts down enough ink to see what I am doing when marking parts in my home garage, yet doesn't "flood" whatever I am writing on with too much ink. It's a tough balancing act for a pen manufacturer to pull off but this works well. I need it to write legibly on many surfaces, often with oil or grease on them and that is a really tough thing to ask any pen to do. What I like best is probably that it leaves just the correct amount of ink to see without looking like a Marks-A-Lot. And ultimately, whatever I write on that upsets my wife is something she is able to also clean & remove easily enough to spare ME hearing her screech in my ear for an hour afterwards.....I can only address usage of this in my garage and hobby areas since I don't write much if ever on paper so I apologize for not being able to address it's obvious target. It is however a wonderful pen for a man used to writing his Last Will & Testament every single time he leaves his garage to reenter his lovely wife's house. Life ain't easy for an old retired guy. I do LOVE the use of it on all my appointment calendars. This is simply a very nice pen at a very nice price.
summary: My "GO TO" Pen For My Garage

reviewText: Item as described, with prompt shipping - two thumbs way up!

The older I get the more I believe in "buy once, cry once." Spend a little more money on good quality products that get the job done, need to be replaced less often, and generally make your life better. I thought Moleskine was for snobs and didn't see anything wrong with a $1 spiral. Then I went back to school, and realized what a pain spirals are. I started taking notes on Ampad narrow ruled paper with a double thick pack, micro-perforated at the top. This works great for general lecture notes, but sometimes you need a notebook.

For example, I'm a literary studies major and one of my profs requires a reading journal. I have to turn in the whole thing several times a semester. I had purchased a Moleskine planner (because it had Peanuts characters on it, mainly) and fell in love with the smooth, supple paper and narrow ruled lines. I thought I might try the cahier journals because they are not terribly expensive in the kraft paper version. I had my husband, an artist, decorate the covers.

They are perfect notebooks. Great size, sturdy, well-sewn, lay flat, the lines are beautifully narrow, the paper is luxuriously smooth and thin without being too thin, and in general they are a joy to write in. Definitely worth about $5 a piece or more.

I use a Bic Atlantis pen which is extremely smooth-writing so these two together - each stroke of the pen is like a stick of buttah.
Well thought out and made. It has helped me clean up my desk and be more efficient.
I immediately starting using these after purchase and they are great. They don't break when using or leave any marks.
Butt saver!!! Really helps with sitting all day.

This is a useful little white board and I keep it in my kitchen. It's small, so it fits on the front of my fridge. The small strip of cork is great for pinning coupons to and I can jot anything I need on the white board portion. The colors are a bit of an odd mix (red, black, and a sort of olive color), but I'm not terribly picky. I like that the markers stay attached by magnets.

I used to have one of these by another brand, but the cork eventually peeled from the white board and curled up. I'll be curious to see how long this board lasts.

Overall, this little white board serves a useful purpose and doesn't take up too much space. Definitely a useful tool in the house!
summary: Small and useful- definitely worth the price!

Many of the "precision" pruners looked flimsy, so I took a chance on these. They are compact enough to slip into a cargo pocket and make precision cuts, but are built like a proverbial brick s***house. The large holes are actually designed to be big enough for both hands when cutting through something thick. I have very large hands, so I have no problem using these with one hand. Someone with very small hands might find them difficult to use, but I can't think of any other possible criticism. I expect them to last for the rest of my life.

reviewText: Great product

I really like this stapler. It strange to be excited about a stapler but this stapler is just really nice. Its built solid and sturdy. It feels nice in your hand. I like the way its shaped and the contour. It works well too. I always hate having to try and get a standard staple through a large amount of paper. What is really nice is that it is a full strip stapler meaning that it will take a full strip of staples instead of having to break a strip up to fit into the stapler. With my other stapler, you have to break the strip in pieces to get it to fit. That always wastes staples and I just don't like breaking them up.

Pricing is a bit erratic for this item. I have the red one and the pricing at the time I write this review is $24 while the blue one is going for $5! I don't know whats up with that. Color doesnt matter to me.

Another issue is the staples. It works with the standard staples that I have but then of course, they aren't high capacity so they will only handle a small amount of papers. The Leitz staples look like regular staples but longer for the added paper capacity. Ive looked around on Amazon for the Leitz high capacity staples and couldn't really figure out which ones were to be used with this stapler. They aren't featured as sold together etc.

Good product

The actual product dimensions is 1.5 x 1.1 x 4.5 inches.

The description says: Product Dimensions: 1.6 x 3.3 x 5.6 inches.

It's too low and doesn't fit the gap on my door! $6.98 for nothing!

It's my fault I didn't look at the description closer. I thought I was getting regular 8.5 x 11 sheets like previous labels I've ordered. These are small 4 x 6 sheets that I can't print with my current printer. Like all Avery labels I've tried so far, they are a very nice quality of paper and adhesive. The Avery website has easy to use templates, but they are limiting in some ways. I usually put the dimensions in Word and create my own template so I can use my artwork for certain homemade items. This allows me to also print right off the edge and manipulate it a little more than Avery.com allows.

Overall, I hesitant to recommend these unless you understand they're just 4x6 sheets. ;) Some people like that so they can print only what they need, but I found with the larger sheets I just print the ones I need and I can send the sticker sheet through the printer sans already used stickers without a problem.

The picture is a little misleading - they really are only 1 7/8" across. Use a ruler to make sure you have the right size. I needed 2" and thought whats 1/8" anyway? Well, it really is a lot - especially with the scallops. They're cute though!

reviewText:
**Please don't buy any more HP consumer level products**

I had a 2.5 year old C5180 all in one. I have probably printed 10 or less full color photos (which came out great) Suddenly today I have multiple ink failures--color cartridges that were between 30% and 80% full all show empty even though I was able to print in color the day before.

I followed the exact procedures on HP's website to reset the printer to no avail. I am a software / hardware engineer and know my way around electronics.

Their business / laser printers seem to be quality, but all their regular consumer stuff seems to be built to work great for a year or two and then die, forcing you to buy again. Not to mention their psycho ink prices.

So, once again my HP printer died after warranty, and all they want to do for me is to either:
1) Sell me a new or refurbished printer at a 'discount' which ends up being at or near (within $20) current Amazon prices!
2) Charge me $45 to troubleshoot the printer

Don't be stupid like I was. This is the third printer I've had issues with, and will not make the same mistake again.  I urge everyone else to look elsewhere for printers.
summary: Don't buy any HP consumer level products!

I wanted to wait for a few months before writing this review.  I've been using the Earthing Pad for about 3 months, and in that time, I have noticed, pretty much zero difference.  I still feel the negative effects of electric devices, still tire out in front of a computer, pretty much nothing has changed as far as that's concerned -- and that's the reason why I bought this.

The whole pseudoscience behind Earthing sounds cool, but I'm not fooled by placebo.  Things actually have to work in real life for me, and I'm sorry, but I really notice little to no beneficial effects from using this pad.  I wish I did.  I honestly do.  I'm into all of this alternative health stuff.  But this Earthing pad, can't say I recommend it.

Update: 1/18/12: 7 months, wanted to add to my original review.  For some strange reason (probably all of the David Wolfe hype), I kept using this thing to see if it made ANY difference.  I feel absolutely NOTHING still to this day, 7 months of daily use.  I'm convinced that the majority of 5-star reviews on here are planted.  Every "real life" person I know who have used this pad notice nothing.  Notice how the reviews are pretty much either 5 stars or 1 star?  It's because the 5 star reviews are phony.
summary: Doesn't seem to do a thing for me

reviewText: These are great envelopes for small items. They will hold 8 x 11 inch papers, but there is a limit on how many pages will fit into one envelope Basically the greater the number of pages, the sooner you'll reach the height (thickness) limit of placing papers into a single envelope. For other items, the thicker (height) of the item, the smaller the outside dimensions must be to successfully fit inside the envelope. As an example, a 3" x 7' box will fit, providing its height is 1" or less.

If you organize your life around a wall calendar, this is the one to get.  This calendar is flip style with the wire coil at the top, and a metal rod within the coil that allows hanging the calendar without it tearing through the paper. like the cheaply made calendars do.  I also appreciate that there are no stupid pictures I have to look at every day, just full size lined squares to write in the information I need.  The bottom edge of the calendar has all twelve months listed so you don't have to flip through the calendar to see what day is on what date.  The only thing I caution about is using certain permanent markers that will bleed through the paper and mark on the succeeding sheet, so I recommend only using gel-style pens or something that won't soak through the paper.  Each date has a small "running total" of days elapsed and days to come for the yearly 365 days, and all the major holidays are listed, plus some other ones that I never even heard of.  The more major holidays have the date in red.  I think these are federally-celebrated holidays.  This is not a small calendar, filling a 23" by 15.5" space on my kitchen wall.  But a good 80% of the calendar can be used for recording information, as opposed to the less-than-50% of calendars that have the top half as a pretty picture.  A lot cheaper price here on Amazon than at the local office supply store, as is usually the case with Amazon.  Highly recommended for those of us who need to keep an organized list of places to go, people to see and things to do.

I do wish the tape didn't have such a long strip of unusable tape at the beginning of the roll, it seems like such a waste of product!

I have two single keys that I have for work, so I ordered this attractive looking lanyard to replace my boring plain black one. I absolutely love the way it looks-- it's so pretty. Today is the first day wearing it, and it's totally useless!! I have my TWO single keys on it, which not heavy at all--and the lanyard keeps falling right off of my neck!!  Without even touching it! I was literally just sitting at my desk and it fell off. It also fell off twice as I was walking, too--again--not even touching it!!
I have absolutely no idea how this thing got so many good reviews when it doesn't even stay on!! I would be afraid to trust keeping my important keys on it because they would be lost in no time. I'm very disappointed because it's so pretty, but, it's just not useable because it falls right  off for no reason. I would absolutely not recommend this lanyard.

UPDATE--January 7, 2015****I've given this lanyard more of a chance, and it's actually much better than it was. I've changed my rating from one star to three stars. At least I understand it now! It still opens up and/or falls off a few times per day, but, somehow I know when it's going to happen and I grab it and fix it. I guess the magnet is there so it doesn't actually "break", although I'm not really sure what it's there for. I'm so glad I can still wear this to carry my two single keys because it's so pretty. Still not sure if I would buy again or recommend to others, though.
summary: Totally Useless!! Falls Right Off!!--(UPDATE-A Bit Better).

He's elderly so the lack of "fussy" buttons on the base is a plus.  It also eliminated the need for a phone jack in his bedroom.  The lighted keypad is useful & the talking caller ID is great. This is a great binding machine for the cost.  I have been using a GBC binder for decades.  The wire binding is much nicer and the TruBind TB-S20A Coil Binding Machine is easy to use.  The puncher works well though it would be nice if it punched more pages, though not an issue.  The coil spinning wheel does go fast but it only took a minute to figure out how to easily use it.  Some manual guidance for the coil is necessary, but that is to be expected.  It does get the job done.  I highly recommend this binding machine for those who make a few booklets or manuals daily.  It might be hard to use and time consuming for mass production.

I really like Epson and the prints from this printer (meaning photos) are excellent.  I appreciate the speed as well as the accuracy in colors this printer has.  If I have any complaint at all it would be with the software/drivers. Okay the one thing that works much better on this model (as it did on my old 2530) is the software installation and drivers.  They work so much better on this than the WF-4640 or the WF 7610 I use at my office. Both of those get lost literally off of my PC in the middle of printing some pages.  For example I will print two of something then go right back a minute later to print a couple more only to have the printer not be able to be found by my PC and this is while the printer is attached with a USB cable.
So this is a small and hard working printer that dose all it does pretty consistently and well.
summary: Great little printer and make sure you get the 220 Ink not the 200 as I did as it looks just the same!

This is a really fun art book for parents to do together with toddlers.  It is especially appealing to kids, like my two-year old, who are entranced with scissors. It contains everything you need, except the scissors and crayons, to create scenes that involve cutting, pasting and coloring.

It's a lot of fun to be able to use so many skills within a single project. And I like how well-contained it it.  We can start on a project and when my child is bored, close up the book and continue it at another time.

The only thing that would make it better would be to include a pair of child-friendly scissors with the book.  If you don't have some, you'll have to buy them before you can enjoy this. If you have a pair already, you are ready to have fun.
summary: Activity kit within a single book

I have two others that claim to be "Medium" nibs, but one is closer to a fine and the other may well be what I'd call a medium nib.

Other than that, I think the color is spectacular, I like a pen with a little weight and this one fits the bill. Not a light pen at all. I suppose if I wrote for hours at a time I'd change my mind.

reviewText:
I bought these in the hopes that I could lengthen my Prismacolor colored pencils when they got too short. At nearly $2 per pencil, I want to use all I can of it. Neither of the pencil holders held them correctly. They would slide in and out. I finally had to jury rig one of them with a piece of a rubber glove but that isn't the reason I bought them.

So, with a little effort, you can hold your Prismacolor colored pencils in the silver one with a tiny piece of rubber, shelf lining or fun foam stuck along one side of the pencil.

Of the art and colored pencils I have, these are how they fit. I hope this helps.
The silver one will hold Blick Studio colored pencils, Crayola Metallic pencils, Derwent Metallic Pencils & Staedtler Aquarell pencils (3 sided)

The black one will hold Faber-Castell artist pencils, Faber-Castell colored pencils, Koh-I-Noor colored pencils. I do not know if this is relevant or not but each of the pencils I noted here are 6 sided. Maybe that is why they fit better?
summary: Only fits Prismacolor colored pencils with a bit of jury rigging.

reviewText: These worked great for storing some of our nicer clothing during a move. Based on some reviews I was worried they wouldn't make it but the boxes stayed intact and everything stayed hanging on the bars. After inserting the bars into their slots I used packing tape to secure them to the cardboard sides which might have helped. The boxes are pretty sturdy. They are not tall enough to hang longer items such as dresses without them touching the bottom, so if that's a concern you may want to search for taller boxes; however my clothes came out unwrinkled. I would purchase these again.

This cart is totally cute.  I keep a yard stick by my computer so I can scope out the size of items based on measurements listed.  This was especially helpful since some reviewers mentioned this cart was small.  The size is perfect for my use.  I have a tabletop easel and I needed something to hold my paints/brushes that would sit beside my chair.  This cart is perfect.  It is sturdy, attractive and holds more than I expected.  The color is true to that pictured on my monitor--a medium turquoise (teal?).  It is also great that it has bars on both sides and across the back which will keep containers from sliding off.

For DIYers, it is important to partially insert all screws before tightening them.  Even so the last two screws were a royal pain.  The screws fit when inserted into the tray alone but when I tried to screw them through the frame and the tray I couldn't get them lined up.  So I used two pointed screws the same size which I had on hand--problem solved.  The wheels aren't the best but the cart is on a wood floor and it rolls smoothly enough for my purposes.  If the wheels stopped working, the cart, even loaded with my supplies, is light enough to pick up and place in another location if I needed to do so.

This cart is worth the money and I definitely would buy it again.  If I had a need or the room, I'd buy another.  For those with limited space, this cart would be an asset because it holds a lot of stuff, it is sturdy enough to hold the stuff and looks rich for the price.  Really, really like this little cart.
summary: A great little cart for small spaces.

reviewText: Just like the ones from the office supply store.

I spent my day testing this out for a perfect copy, It copies the way you drag it across your document. To perfect each copy, I took a piece of cardboard, glued a stick to the side, a cheap ruller will work, to have a perfect straight line to copy by.. I then folded a thick paper to hold the document, it was  glued with less than a 1/4 in fold overhang. to frame the document. About 1/2 inch from the stick, according to the scanner guide line. I made another folded paper guide on the other side to keep the paper from shifting. I laid the cardboard holder on a mouse pad to keep it from shifting. I can put a document on the cardboard holders & guide the scanners for 3 seconds with both hands & turn out perfect copies, all on the memory chip. Then I put the micro sd memory in the adapter to fit usb or sd adapter, & check or print out from computer. It works on rechargeable batteries, & 8 gigs memory will hold 4000 documents, I am guessing that the rechargeable battery will probably copy 50 pages per charge. The scanner is just a portable stick & the scanner guide that I made will be slightly larger than a page & will fit in any folder. I got tired of the big scanners that are delicate, clumbsy, & has to be programed. I used no cables, no programming, but I move the memory chip to where I want the scanned information, up to the 4000 copies that an 8 gig chip will hold. it takes at least 3 seconds to a copy, & at least 3 seconds to set up each page. It is free of frustration, convenient & portable.  Just be careful when opening the package, it could slide out onto the floor when you open the package.

my Brother scanner was defective in the first year,..the support was terrible. I spent so much time on chats and on the phone with them and they never resolved my issue of poor scan quality. They kept linking me to the same "cleaning instructions",..finally, after so much time they tell me that now the machine is out of warranty!
My next office printer will be a Samsung...,or anything but Brother.

did not last long at all not what they said.

July 2009 and it's still working really well ... in a busy practice ... January 2010; still great, very few fumes unlike the Brother machines, very very few paper jams; all in all an excellent machine!

Hi - other peoples' reviews helped me choose this machine so I am writing in.

This machine was very easy to set up = good
And the copy quality is excellent; even patients have remarked

The faxing from the glass takes several time-consuming steps; if you fax a sheet from the glass you have to hit the fax button, then '1-button' (for on the glass) and then 'check-button' that the paper is set to fax, and then wait until the sheet is scanned and then I have to hit '2-button' (that there is not another sheet to fax so it will actually send it, and if I forget it won't just send it ...) - too many steps for a very busy practice.

The ringer was set at the lowest ring and it was very loud, the help desk is fantastic and they walked through turning it off because it would not go lower.

It does not come with a manual, maybe a good thing so we save paper, but it is on the internet and as I had stated, the help staff is wonderful.

It is attractive and small for an all-in-one -

I had the Brother and it gave me many problems from the start - mostly the top paper feed would suck up too many papers (very bad when I'm faxing medical charts ...) and it was hard to cancel a fax so I really despised that machine, this paper feed seems excellent and I have not had any problems with several papers being sucked in, but it will not take slightly crumpled papers; then I am back to using the glass top...

The Brother let out terrible fumes; this one has not bothered me even after many copies in a row.

I just changed out my first new ink and I was able to print 1882 pieces of paper including faxes that came in; is that good?

One problem, is that the machine will say that I am out of paper when I have an inch or so of paper left, the help desk person said I need to clean the rollers,  ... my brother did the same thing, but it would jam and then I would have to open all the doors, pull out ink etc, this one does not make me go through so many tedious actions...

I have an extremely busy and sometimes stressful job and so these seemingly small problems are occasionally magnified ... over all it is a very nice machine and serves its purpose well.  Is it the dream machine.... no.

Several months later I want to add that I have had very few paper jams, the top slot that sucks in papers to copy or fax is fantastic, and I am happy I got this machine - I would certainly recommend it.
summary: good, but faxing from the glass is not so great ...

This Mustek large format scanner is a real bargain at the price. I always wanted a scanner that could handle larger size graphics but couldn't afford the high cost, until this one came along. It makes great scans and is fast and easy to use. Scan quality is excellent and I am surprised by how fast it actually scans a full color page. The software and drivers installed with no problem on my Windows XP machine (an old one at that) and it co-exists with my Microtek scanner with no issues. It comes with a very basic control panel that lets you scan or copy directly, but this is really not the way to use this machine. Instead, if everything is installed properly, you launch the scanner through the TWAIN option in your image processing software, make some basic settings in the menu that pops up and then scan directly into the image program. I use Photoshop Elements and it put the Mustek scanner into its TWAIN (import) menu with no problem. The scanner has preview and final scan functions. You can resize the scan frame to suit the size of the material being scanned and there is a batch scan option also.

There are some things you need to be aware of when installing this machine. It is very lightweight and will scoot around the worktable when you open the lid and position the paper to be scanned. It needs to be placed up against something heavy. Second, the USB cable must be plugged direcly into the USB port on the back of the computer. I tried going though a powered USB hub but the computer could not find the scanner. This tip is on the Mustek website. Third, the scanning program that opens through TWAIN is very basic and unsophisticated. As far as I could tell, Silverfast does not make a compatible version. You just have to handle most of your adjustments through your photo editing software such as Photoshop.

Overall, this scanner handles the basic chores with no problems and won't break your bank account.
summary: Great Scans and Easy to Use

reviewText: Item as described, 5 star happy!

This was a must-have for my new office area. I'm pretty happy with it. It probably would have been smart to measure the area it would be used, though, because a slightly larger one would have been helpful. (The same manufacturer has several different sizes.) Part of the reason I went for the smaller one was price. I feel like this it was a bit overpriced for what amounts to a big flat piece of plastic. reviewText:
I've had this for several months now, and I am quite happy with it.  I wanted to share some information on putting this item together that might be helpful to others.  First, the two half-round black plastic pieces that have to be put together around each corner for each shelf and the handle do not fit together perfectly nor do they need to as it turns out--something I wish I had known beforehand.  Surprisingly enough, these plastic pieces will be covered (but not completely) by the shelf/handle providing a nice sturdy base for the shelf or handle. That was certainly not apparent when I started putting this together.  Also, make sure you are putting these two pieces together and on the pole right.  Each half has "top" marked on one end, but the word is embossed in the plastic which doesn't stand out greatly.

Next, there is no clear indication where exactly these plastic pieces go on the pole.  I found that if I put the pieces together up a little higher than needed, pressed them into one another and slid them down the pole, they made a clearly heard and felt snapping sound so that you know they are in place.

Last, slide the shelf on gently and make sure the black plastic sleeves are all going inside the shelf holes.  Just barely get them started so that all sides will go down smoothly once you are sure all the plastic sleeves are in place.

Maybe I'm an idiot, but I couldn't tell which way the bottom shelves went on--side pieces up as a mini tray or down. If I had come to the site I would have seen "up" like a mini tray was the answer by looking at the photo.  The drawing included does not clearly show it, however.  There is also writing on the corners which is right side up this way--dead give away, so, okay, I am an idiot.

Overall I'm impressed with the quality of the materials. The cart is quite sturdy in an industrial chic kind of way. If you are looking for a delicate-looking piece, this is not the one for you.  I saw that there are some grayish plastic inserts that can be purchased separately if you want to prevent things from falling through the holes in the shelves. That would really take away from the look for me.  If I find I need something, I will have glass or plexiglass cut for it.  At this point, I am using it as my coffee bar and have nothing that will fall through.

 I saw some reviews mentioning product damage on arrival.  Mine was in perfect shape.  It was well packed with one box inside another for extra protection.  All pieces were included and in perfect condition. I was able to easily put this together by myself despite the less than ideal directions.

If I didn't feel a need to prevent others from some initial confusion as they push those plastic pieces together only to find that that other side separates, I'd give this five stars.
summary: A few hints for putting this together....

I replaced a black cartridge and after two tries, it was recognized and worked. The yellow ran out, and when I tried to replace it, I kept getting an error that the printer did not recognize the cartridge. Tried taking it out and pushing it back in like 10 times. The cartridge seats and the release lever clicks in place, but it won't work. Without all cartridges working, the printer won't print. I cant take the chance of having a cartridge fail and my whole printer goes down.....sucks.

This was, at the time I bought it, the best value per pack on Amazon and I can't complain so far.  The pad is ruled a little larger than I am used to and the cardboard backing isn't as rigid as other products, but, then again, none of them were this cheap per unit.  It does exactly what I need it to.  Will buy again.  Enough said.

It sure looks like it should have a motor in it (considering the cost and that the box says that it is a two-step operation), but it doesn't.  You have to physically push each image through, then press the same button twice (once to scan, a second time to save) -- that's a 3-step operation for each image, not a 2-step.  It does not scan, but photographs slides / film that are backlit (pay attention that the box says "converter" not "scanner"), so it is rather fast to capture images, but at a price: quality.

The quality is at best mediocre and the tray slides and wiggles even when inserted, such that your slides can often look slightly crooked every time.  Another annoyance is that you have to turn the scanner off to disconnect the scanner from the computer, or to get back to the main screen after using the scanner.  If your images require color correction, you have to do them one at a time, which isn't much of an issue if you have a computer and photoshop, but if the intent of the machine was to bypass the computer, it's not very convenient.

There are flatbed scanners out there, designed to scan slides and film at extremely higher resolutions.  They take much longer, but the quality is exceedingly better.

This product appears to specifically target people who want to make smallish (4x6) prints or to display on a TV screen, and that's it.  If you thought that this might be a good way to digitize your Ektachrome slides for posterity, you're looking at the wrong product.
summary: Be careful of what you want to use this for.

reviewText:
A few months ago at a local discount store I purchased over a dozen rolls of some off-brand packing tape for 99 cents per 55 yard roll. In some ways it's similar to this Duck Brand tape. It's 3.0 mil thick, whereas the Duck is 3.1 mil. The cheap stuff is the same width as this tape, and has pretty good stickability for a cheap tape.

So far I haven't used the cheap tape for much shipping during the wet season, and I've been concerned about how well it will hold up under rainy and snowy conditions. I use it liberally because it was cheap, and then just to be safe, I reinforce wherever I need to with a higher quality tape. That's where this Duck Brand tape fits in. It has a different texture than the cheap tape, and does not tear as easily. The cheap stuff feels sort of like a thick cellophane, whereas the Duck Brand is acrylic. I did a side-by-side test on a shipping box, and the Duck Brand definitely sticks more easily and is harder to tear off.

If you don't mind paying the premium price, this tape might be worth it for you for the peace of mind. Just note that it has less tape per roll than some others. The three rolls together give you 131 yards.

They arrived much quicker than expected (within 2 days of ordering). The only thing is that they are more of a seafoam green rather than a mint/turquoise color. They seem very sturdy, thus far. Worth the price as far as we can see :)

In addition, the adhesive label is slightly too.  The sheet is perforated in half, but the label covers the perforation.  That means that the "receipt half" of the sheet still has some of the label on it.

The repositionable labels from Avery held a print from the inkjet printer fine.
I was able to attach, remove, attach remove and they still held to the envelope.

Confusion: I suppose there are a few instances for this 're-hesive' technology - but why would one want to attach a label and then remove it, only to re-attach?  In my experience, the only reason to remove a label would be because of an incorrect address - thus it would be destroyed.  Other than compulsive personalities, I've no idea the need for these.

Other thoughts and finds: while I didn't do an in depth comparison, I quickly found a website selling both RE-HESIVE and PERMANENT - the re-hesive label was slightly more in cost than the original permanent stick label.

After pulling off and removing 3 times, the edges did start to curl and the label adhered to the envelope at my desk, but I fear it would not have made it through any abusive transit system.  Anything could catch an curled corner edge and tear it off.
Lastly, these are noted as being GUARANTEED SMUDGE PROOF - well be sure to purchase appropriate labels for injet vs laser printing.  The inkjet labels DID smudge after printed in my laser printer.

All in all - if, in the past, you've ever wanted to remove a label and re-use it, then I suppose you would love to use these.  I've been in business over 10 years and my thoughts are:
I have no need for this type of label.  The additional cost, no matter how minimal, would be a waste of money for my business and home office.  And to top that off, I would still be concerned to send out a package with an easily removed label for fear the package would never make to its destination.  I want and need a label that's going to stick to the package, through rain, sleet, snow and mail handlers hands.

reviewText:
I have been using the Crayola pencils, which I have found to be very nice.  I got these on one of those "sale" things, and thought it would be great to get another set as the Crayolas are getting a little short due to usage.  These are much harder lead, one has to use a LOT of force to get most of the colors to work.  The colors are very waxy and often "skip" so you have a bit of blank space that no color will attach to because the wax took over.  Also, the paler colors (light yellow, yellow, tan, peach) had weird dark marks in them, which I finally realized was actually IN the lead, as my yellow had a blob of blue in it. After I realized it, I was able to sharpen the pencil and get the blue out of it, but not before my drawing was pretty much ruined. (It was as if when they mixed the batter, they didn't dissolve all the parts, like if you get a chunk of flour in your brownie...) Also, there are many, many shades of green, and very few shades of red.  Also, there are 2 white and 2 black pencils, so you don't even get 50 colors, just 48.  And who really needs a white pencil?  Especially if the others are so waxy, you can't draw over a previous color in order to shade....
At least they were on sale.
summary: Not great, very waxy, colors badly mixed

I'm not sure how they can advertise this as won't bleed through paper and then put a disclaimer on it. The facts are it won't bleed through a good quality writing paper.  Which is true of most ball pens as well, but the goal here is a soft point with the same characteristics of a good ball pen.  It does have an advantage though, the soft point will write easily on very slick paper.  Most ball pens will skip or not write at all if the paper is slick there is not enough resistance to effectively roll the ball.  Of course like ball pens too whatever is written on slick paper will smear easily until it fully dries.

Like the description a more professional look than a lot of inexpensive pens, a solid red color this version and a decent fine point to match one of the more common automatic pencil leads.  As I said though if you hold this down or use it slowly on a very porous paper like newsprint, it does bleed and spreads or goes all they way through the paper.  Still I like knowing when I write things or fill out forms that my pen is going to work, so these are good for that.  Recommended an inexpensive pen that does the job well.
summary: Although the ink smears on slick paper and will bleed through newsprint, does a good job on standard to high quality paper.

reviewText:
Great product!

One caveat - the plastic ink cartridge on the ink dispensing side doesn't look exactly like the OEM product - nozzles seem to be missing and different plastic extensions that are there on the Brother cartridge are not there on this clone.  I don't know how it works or why it works even though it looks far different from the manufacturer version, but it works, and that's all that matters ultimately.  So if you look at it and it seems that you were shipped the wrong product, don't worry, it works - slip it into the slot and you'll see(the non-ink dispensing sides of the cartridge match the manufacturer); so that's the key - as long as it fits into the slot like the OEM cartridge did.

The reviewer who says that he is going to hold the distributor liable for a defective product is out of line.  You pay 1/10 of the cost of a Brother cartridge for this clone, so after 3 cartridges you've already paid for the printer, which is disposable like a bad razor shaver, and you'll break even very quickly.  After that its pure profit.  I'm not even sure that the ink cartridge will do damage to your printer, but if it does down the line, you'll still be way ahead.  So why threaten to sue this dealer, who's providing you with a great deal and saving you tons of money?
summary: Great Product - ignore the reviewer who threatens to hold the dealer liable

I have been in the medical field for years (first nursing and now nurse anesthesia) and I know of no better pens than zebra's for writing in small spaces required by all the charting that we have. And the Zebra F-402 is king among them all in that it is durable, comfortable to grip, and gives quality and consistent inking. The problem with many zebra pens is that they break at the interface where you screw them off because most are plastic so you can only refill them once or twice. The F-402 doesn't have this problem so it is not abnormal to have one of these pens last for years.

So the only reason why I buy the 12-pack is because these are the most stolen pens I know of. Everybody wants them.
summary: Best pens for writing in small spaces

reviewText: Good Cards for Comfort...

I'm a diehard Moleskine fan, but these Treasure Notebook journals looked lovely and I was curious to try one out....and now I'm glad I did.  These are beautiful, well-made notebooks that any journaler would enjoy using.

Pros:
-thick quality paper, no worries about bleeding through here like some cheaper journals
-nice size - bigger than the pocket Moleskines I usually use, but a great size to slip into a purse or bookbag, with lots of room on the page without being too bulky
-lovely hardcover made with soft leather in a beautiful blue shade - I hope they release more color options soon!
-320 pages=LOTS of words.  Appreciate the length

Cons:
-the first lined page is stuck to the end-paper at the binding, so it can't be opened all the way because of the way it's glued together
-the binding isn't quite as high quality as I'd have liked, I don't think this will be quite as durable as my Moleskines
-this is just a personal preference, but I wish the stamp for the brand was on the back of the journal, not the front.  I like my front cover to be nice and blank, not branded

All in all, I'm very pleased with this journal, despite the minor cons listed above.  If you're interested in trying a new brand, this is a great option to check out!

I received a discount on this product in exchange for testing, inspecting and reviewing it.  I received no other compensation for my review and always give my honest and unbiased opinion of each product.  I welcome your questions & comments on my experience.
summary: beautiful journal with only a few minor issues

They told me to send two of the four back for an exchange.  The two scales they mailed back did the same thing.  I was then told by their customer service there was nothing I could do and the scales just did not work well with Windows 8.1.  Great for me since only half of my computers were running that OS.  Moved the scales to my Windows 7 PC's and they worked fine for 5-6 months.  Now all the sudden they are connecting and disconnecting randomly and entering .02oz for the weight of everything.  I've tried new USB cords and swapping them out for one another, even different PCs with no luck.  You might want to think twice if you are hoping for a long term solution here.

reviewText:
This phone has all the capabilities I need and out of the box, is great. It allows me to use a headset, has a mute button, capability for three-way calling and a speakerphone. So, at first blush, I'd give this easily 5 stars- I haven't found another phone that does what this does.

However, in the last year, I've gone through three of these phones. Yes, three. Why? Well, because I use the headset jack...I don't take the headset in and out, by the way. I just keep it in because I don't want to cause undue damage by constantly removing the headphones. However, they STILL break. I just don't really understand it!

The problem is that I can't seem to find another phone that really fills my needs. So, in that case, I end up buying new phones to replace these, recognizing that I'll probably have to replace that headset in a few months. I wish that these were sturdier because then I would not be going on my fourth phone in a year.
summary: Great in the short term- but beware if you need to use headsets!

reviewText:
I purchased the 10 Panel w/ the Articulate Arm that attaches to a desk or table...

Interesting item... a bit different than what I thought but I still like it, I'll get used to it. Firstly PRO's, it is exactly as picture describes and is super easy to put together. The pages are durable, and comparable to past reference organizers. It sits nicely and I have it pushed back right up against the wall, kinda suspended above my phone.

There were comments about the pins being plastic, they are, they are a thick plastic, But, you would have to really get rough with it to break them... don't see them as a problem. Maybe take a deep breath and use some patience sticking the pages in? Really not that hard. They pop right in.

There are also comments about this "sticking out alot". Idk, I have it right above my phone on the narrowest side of my desk, against a wall, and it's pretty flush with the wall, when I have it open it is still pretty flat against the wall, a little sticks out, but not excessively. I can easily access my phone with it there.

CON: It's really not a hydraulic smooth thing you can pull and push around. Those black knobs you see in the picture are to tighten and loosen the movable aspect. So, you can tighten it so you can move it down to you, and up, but after 1-2 movements those knobs will need to be tightened again. I guess I was thinking it was more like a hydraulic arm or something that held its own. I did put in some pages both portrait and landscape, you can use it easily either way. BUT to change from one way to another is a pain, like I said, you have to keep adjusting those knobs. So I just minimized the pages and have everything in portrait view. But you can fully use this for landscape pages as well.

Another thing that's weird is the thing that clamps to the desk, and the arm are just connected via, the arm sits over the clamp area. So it swivels super easy, but there is nothing there to hold the arm on, so if you lift it up it kinda wants to come off. It's about 6 inches so unless you are super aggressive (refer back to my patience comment above) it will not come off, but it is just something to get used to. :)

I like it. It makes my life easier and I've only had it for less than a day. Worth the money.

They are very well made and solid; sit flat, don't wobble, don't feel or look cheap and actually have some weight to them. Each comfortably fits about 50 of my business cards. They look professional which is great. The only con is they do slide a bit on a bare desk, so maybe a set of rubber feet would have been nice, but I don't expect them to get up and walk away anytime soon, so it's not a big deal. Overall, I would highly recommend these!

reviewText:
These cards are handy & attractive heavy paper for DIY table tents. I like the embossed border, and they produce a clean, crisp print. They're convenient and give a clean, unified, professional appearance to whatever your application (panel tables, shop shelves, buffet table). They also coordinate with other sizes of the same product, if you have call for different sizes. They come 2-up, widthwise, on a letter size page and tear cleanly with microperforation.

I would describe them as heavyweight paper, or lightweight cardstock. The weight is less flimsy in the medium tents than the large ones.

Since the focus here is more on easy customization than a durable product, so I don't think the material is inappropriate to its use. But do understand that these are throwaways; you won't be reusing them for multiple events unless you're the typle to successfully reuse wrapping paper. But they are attractive, and they'll still do nicely for short-term shop signage, as long as they're not by a door (breezes).

Ooma makes money on its VOIP interface boxes.

No shocker, then, that Ooma effectively refuses to reactive used units. But why the lies: Various claims that original accounts remain active or that an original account has been suspended -- different calls on the same unit actually got three different no-way answers. The active excuse is somewhat suspect: Why would someone sell the box and still pay the monthly service fee? One customer service rep "confirmed" that the original owner still was paying monthly fees as I held his box in my hand.

As for the second unit, my seller claims Ooma confirmed that he closed his account on 10/11/2011. This was the second Amazon Marketplace purchase. (I get it now. But there will be no third-time with a new Ooma.)

BUT EVEN IF YOU WERE ALLOWED TO REACTIVE, Ooma customer service (sic) says it would insist on a $79 reactivation charge. That charge, a rep insists, is right there in the Terms and Conditions. Well, certainly not any $79 figure, just an oblique mention that Ooma reserves the right to charge an activation fee (unspecified). It is buried in a list of other fees, etc., etc.

Hence purchasers of used unit "shall forfeit all rights, privileges, and licenses herein and herein contained, et cetera, et cetera... Fax mentis incendium gloria cultum, et cetera, et cetera... Memo bis punitor delicatum!" (per Willy Wonka, Esq.)
summary: DANGER: Do Not Buy/Try Used! + Sadly, Ooma's lies change...

reviewText:
Before we go any further I freely admit I did not read the ad or ask an important question.  This review is written so others don't make the same mistake.

This paper is made from wood pulp.  It is NOT cotton rag. It is worse than the Canson paper I bought earlier.  It doesn't accept wet on wet washes without buckling and pilling. Very little water can be absorbed so it just sits on top of the paper and when it dries the pigment is more like soft pastel in that it rubs off so easily.

It might be OK for colored pencil or other non-wet methods of painting/drawing, but it is advertised and labeled as watercolor paper.  It should be labeled as sketching cards, not watercolor.

Another, albeit minor, issue is that the two pads are not the same size!  One of them is nearly 1/32" larger in one dimension.  Not a really big difference, but this stuff is machine made and cut.  If the quality of dimensions is this poor, it speaks loudly to the quality of other aspects of the product and the company.

Again, my fault for not reading the entire ad, but that doesn't make the paper any better than it really is.  Especially for beginning water-colorists, this is one of the worst choices that can be made.
summary: One of the Worst Choices that can be Made

reviewText:
Organizing your documents is definitely a good idea.  I spent an afternoon awhile back getting a lot of our paperwork together in one place  it now fills one drawer in a file cabinet in my home office.  So when I saw this Smead LIFE DOCUMENTS ORGANIZER KIT I thought it sounded interesting  it keeps all of your most important documents in one portable box which can then be stored wherever you like.  Now that Ive had a chance to play around with it a little, Im not sure theres anything in this kit you cant put together on your own for a lot less money.  In fact, you can set up your own filing system that reflects your own life, rather than Smeads version of it.

Included in the kit are the following:
~1 black plastic file box, with a carrying handle
~24 manila file folders
~6 multi-colored hanging file folders
~Pre-printed labels
~1 sheet of plastic hanging file labels (for use with the pre-printed category headings)

The instructions suggest you divide your stuff into six categories  Personal, Ownership, Health, Communication & Wishes, Financials, and Contact Information.  Each category is color-coded to one of the colored hanging file folders, and there are pre-printed file tab labels (also color-coded) to organize your stuff within each category.  Some of these make sense  Health Records should be filed under Health, and Bank Records should be filed under Financials.  But others do not.  For example, the Pets file (which should hold your pets health and license records) is color-coded to be filed under Contact Information, and Safe Deposit Box (in which you store info on your key and location of your safe deposit box) is color-coded to be filed under Communication & Wishes (Ownership might make more sense).  Also, theres a label for Current Bills, which seems odd  its unlikely youll want to keep your current bills in a storage box like this.

Heres the basic problem:  Theres either a lot more here than youll need, or a lot less.  If you have very complicated records, they undoubtedly won't fit in these small folders or this small box.  If you have very simple records, you won't need all these categories and folders.  And its unlikely the pre-printed labels will exactly fit your records.  Yes, you can always print your own, but youll have to buy printable labels, which is an added expense.

Additionally, this isn't a particularly sturdy box.  I have a hanging file box which is approximately the same size, and its much more solid with a much more secure clasp.  This Smead box is designed to look like its metal, but its not.  And the clasp seems quite flimsy  I doubt it will stand up to much opening and closing.

Finally, I have to ask myself whether I want all of these documents stored in the same place  especially a place that is so easily portable.  The suggestion is that youll keep your will, your bank records, your safe-deposit information, and your account passwords in the same box.  Not smart.  That file cabinet I mentioned at the start of this review contains many important documents (titles to our cars, birth certificates, copies of our wills, the deed to our house, our marriage license, etc.).  It does not contain our bank records, investment records, and internet passwords  these things are kept separately.

Bottom line, its a good idea to get organized.  But for less money you could buy a whole lot more file folders and a better-quality box, and then decide for yourself what documents you want to keep in it and how youd like them organized.  I don't really see the value of this kit, beyond inspiring you to set up your own system.
summary: Yes, it's a good idea to get organized . . . but this kit isn't the answer

I bought this printer back in 2013 not knowing what I have since learned about inkjet printers. Up front, you should know that in order to for an inkjet to be useful, it needs to be used regularly--say at least one or a couple times a month; otherwise, the ink clogs up the heads and, not only affects print quality, but will waste TONS of ink from the cartridges as you run a cleaning to unclog. You will spend a lot on consumables (ink), so if you're a sporadic at-home printer like my family, make a switch to laser printers. Yes, inkjets can be cheap (when I bought this model, it was only $60, a popular price point for many models, but you spend much more on frequent printing (sometimes higher than having them professionally printing).

With that out of the way, here is my review of this particular printer. I bought it with the intention of using it for borderless printing for my son's invitations, but you can't really do that for special paper sizes. Works fine for flyers on 8.5x11, but I use special paper sizes for invitations, and even with trying to configure it manually, it would not accept them, and I had to use a machine at work. Print quality was decent, but it expended huge amounts of ink, thus ballooning the price per print to huge levels. It prints about the same speed as other inkjets I've had, so neither fast or terribly slowly, but there is a long startup between spooling the print and actually printing--annoying when you're heading out the door and need a confirmation or something printed.

The scanning works fine and scan quality is decent.

Wireless printing is sporadic. When the power would go out, I would have to reset everything, which is annoying.

The user screen is easy to use and attractive.

The machine is lightweight and average size, taking up the entirety of our little side table.

The reason I gave this machine two stars is simple--after a month and a half of use, a printhead clogged and would not unclog no matter how many times I cleaned it. In total, I maybe got six months out of this machine, frustrating the heck out my husband who is the one who used it more than anyone (which wasn't much).

Bottom line: I made the switch to a monochrome laser and will reserve color printing for the professionals (because I don't print often). Laser may not be great for printing pictures, but I wasn't really printing those at home anyway, and because it uses toner, it never dries out. It prints much faster, and it's also wireless and scans. I will never go back to inkjet, and I suggest that others in my same boat make the switch too.
summary: Inkjets--Cheap Up Front, Expensive in the Longrun
